explanations: The translation expands the concise French rhetorical question into a more explicit statement, identifying 'les Gens de l'Astrée' as 'Shepherds' and detailing their alternative activities, simplifying by making implicit cultural references more accessible.
The formal French interrogative 'de quoy fut-il question?' (of what was it a question?) is simplified to the more direct and common English phrasing 'what was the next thing to be considered?'.
The somewhat elaborate French phrase 'qui s'estoit mis dans la fantaisie que' (who had put it into his fancy that) is simplified to the more common and direct verb 'who fansied that'.

The complex French negative construction 'on ne manqua pas d'abord de s'imaginer qu'il falloit que...' (one did not fail at first to imagine that it was necessary that...) is simplified to a direct affirmative 'Man believed, that the Earth was...', also replacing the impersonal 'on' and simplifying the verb phrase.

The vivid and somewhat dramatic French phrase 'il vous jetteroit dans une épouvante horrible' (it would throw you into a horrible fright) is simplified to the more common and less intense verb 'it would frighten you'.

The concise French 'par lesquels ils sauvoyent toutes ces bizarreries' (by which they saved/accounted for all these oddities), using the technical sense of 'sauver les apparences', is expanded and explained as 'by which they fansy'd to themselves, they understood all the irregular Phaenomena's, or Appearances in Nature', making the concept more accessible.

The somewhat archaic/literary French 'Avoyent-ils nouvelle d'un autre mouvement' (Had they news/wind of another movement) is simplified to a standard conditional structure 'and if any one made a new discovery of any other Motion'.

The complex French negative idiom 'on n'avoit garde d'en vouloir douter' (one took care not to want to doubt it/one was careful not to doubt it) is simplified to the more direct 'no body would adventure to question the truth of it'.

The original's elaborate and emphatic sentence detailing Nature's thrift, including a direct address and conditional clause, is drastically simplified and condensed into a more straightforward statement.

The translator omits the concluding judgmental phrase 'cela est tout-à-fait ridicule' (that is completely ridiculous), reducing the density of the text and removing a direct authorial comment, thus simplifying the rhetorical load.
The translation simplifies by omitting the clause 'où elle s'estoit placée' (where it had placed itself), removing a detail about Earth's previous self-assumed position.
The qualifying phrase 'en quelque sorte' (in a way / sort of) is omitted, making the statement 'it is by chance' more direct and less nuanced, thereby simplifying it.

The long and somewhat convoluted French sentence describing Earth's celestial retinue ('Enfin de tout cet équipage celeste dont cette petite Terre se faisoit accompagner & environner...') is significantly condensed and restructured into a simpler English sentence.

The impersonal French construction 'il vient de vous prendre un enthousiasme qui vous a fait expliquer...' (an enthusiasm has just taken you which has made you explain...) is simplified to a more direct address 'you are in so great a Rapture, and express your self...', and 'je ne croy pas les avoir entenduës' (I don't believe I have understood them) becomes the clearer 'I hardly understand what you mean'.

The concise French 'Je la retrouveray bien' (I will find it/her well enough) is expanded to the more conversational and reassuring 'Do not fear, said I, Madam; I shall soon find her again', simplifying the interaction by making the reassurance explicit.
The strong French 'il estoit bien mal intentionné pour la Terre' (he was very ill-intentioned towards the Earth) is softened and simplified to 'he had no great kindness for the Earth'.

The original phrase '& son coeur ne laisse pas de s'interesser à une affaire de pure speculation.' (and his heart does not fail to take an interest in a matter of pure speculation.) is omitted in the translation, which ends the corresponding thought with 'which consists purely in Speculation.' This omission simplifies by removing a layer of psychological nuance.

The original's description of Copernicus's actions ('He did not want to endure... and skillfully got himself out of the affair') is rephrased into a purpose clause combined with a euphemism, simplifying the complex motivations into a more straightforward narrative of cause and effect.
The French phrase 'cela me feroit bien voir que...' (that would make me see well that...) is simplified to the more concise and common English 'that would convince me,...'.

The repetition in 'Non pas, Madame, ... non pas' is reduced to 'Not at all, Madam'. The translation also adds an explanatory clause 'the Earth changes the Shoar, as well as your Boat', simplifying the inference for the reader by making the analogy explicit.

The general description of motion 'les parties d'en haut viennent en bas, & que celles d'en bas montent en haut' (the parts from above come below, and those from below go up) is simplified by concretizing it into a visual of 'the Mark that is on the Bowl, sometimes above, and sometimes below', making the concept easier to grasp.

The impersonal French 'on ne l'a guere ménagée' (one has hardly spared it) and 'on luy demande bien de l'agilité' (one demands much agility from it) are simplified by specifying 'Copernicus' as the agent and changing the structure to the more active 'making so weighty and solid a Mass run about so nimbly'.
The idiomatic French 'le mouvement ne leur coúte rien' (movement costs them nothing) is simplified to the more common English expression 'swiftness of Motion is easie to them'.

The impersonal French construction 'Et où faudroit-il que la Terre fust cramponnée pour résister... & ne s'y pas laisser emporter?' (And where would it be necessary for the Earth to be clamped... and not let itself be carried away by it?) is simplified into a more direct, active question 'And to what wou'd you fix or grapple the Earth, to hinder it...?' and the complex negative purpose is rephrased more simply.

chunks.source_manual: <P011>Mais, repliqua-t-elle encore, comment la Terre avec tout son poids se soûtient-elle sur vostre matiere celeste, qui doit estre bien legere, puis qu'elle est si fluide? Ce n'est pas à dire, répondis-je, que ce qui est fluide, soit plus leger. Que dites-vous de nostre gros Vaisseau, qui avec tout son poids est plus léger que l'eau, puis qu'il y surnage? Je ne veux plus vous dire rien, dit-elle comme en colere, tant que vous aurez le gros Vaisseau. Mais m'assurez-vous bien qu'il n'y ait rien à craindre sur une piroüette aussi legere que vous me faites la Terre? Et bien, luy repondis-je, faisons porter la Terre par quatre Elephans, comme font les Indiens. Voicy bien un autre Systême, s'écria-t-elle. Du moins j'aime ces Gens-là d'avoir pourveu à leur seureté, & fait de bons fondemens, au lieu que nous autres Coperniciens, nous sommes assez inconsiderez pour vouloir bien nager à l'avanture dans cette matiere celeste. Je gage que si les Indiens sçavoient que la Terre fust le moins du monde en peril de se mouvoir, ils doubleroient les Elephans.</P011> <P012>Cela le meriteroit bien, repris-je, <NCP>en riant de sa pensée</NCP>, il ne faut point s'épargner les Elephans pour dormir en assurance, & si vous en avez besoin pour cette nuit, nous en mettrons dans nostre Systême autant qu'il vous plaira; ensuite nous les retrancherons peu à peu, à mesure que vous vous rassurerez. Serieusement, reprit-elle, je ne croy pas dés à present qu'ils me soient fort necessaires, & je me sens assez de courage pour oser tourner. Vous irez bien-tost encore plus loin, repliquay-je, vous tournerez avec plaisir, & vous vous ferez sur ce Systême des idées réjoüissantes. Quelquefois, par exemple, je me figure que je suis suspendu en l'air, & que j'y demeure sans mouvement pendant que la Terre tourne sous moy en vingt-quatre heures, & que je vois passer sous mes yeux tous ces visages differens, les uns blancs, les autres noirs, les autres bazannez, les autres olivâtres, que je voy d'abord des Chapeaux, & puis des Turbans, & puis des Testes cheveluës, & puis des Testes rases; tantost des Villes à clochers, tantost des Villes à longues aiguilles qui ont des Croissans, tantost des Villes à Tours de Porcelaine, tantost de grands Païs qui n'ont que des Cabanes; icy, des vastes Mers; là des Deserts épouvantables; enfin toute cette variesté infinie qui est sur la surface de la Terre.</P012> <P013>En verité, dit-elle, tout cela meriteroit bien que l'on donnast vingt-quatre heures de son temps à le voir. Ainsi donc dans le mesme lieu où nous sommes à present, je ne dis pas dans ce Parc, mais dans ce mesme lieu à le prendre dans l'air, il y passe continuellement d'autres Peuples qui prennent nostre place, & au bout de vingt-quatre heures nous y revenons.</P013>
chunks.target_manual: <P013>But, said she, how does the Earth support its vast weight, on your Heavenly Substance, which ought to be very light, since it is so fluid? That does not follow, answered I, Madam, that a thing must be light, because it is fluid: What say you to the First-Rate Ship, I spoke of, with all its Lading? Yet 'tis lighter than the Water, because it swims upon it. As long as you command your First-Rate Frigat, said she, angrily, I will not argue with you; but can you assure me, that I am in no danger, by inhabiting such a little Humming-Top, as you have made the World to be? Well, Madam, said I, the Earth shall be supported by four Elephants, as the Indians fansie it is. Here's a new System indeed, cry'd Madam la Marquiese; yet I love those Men, for providing for their own security, by resting upon a solid Foundation; whereas we that follow Copernicus, are so inconsiderate, as to swim at a venture upon your Celestial Matter: And I dare say, if these Indians thought the Earth in any danger of falling, they wou'd quickly double the number of their Elephants. They wou'd have all the reason in the World to do so, said I, Madam; (laughing at her fancy;) and wou'd not spare Elephants to sleep in quiet, without fear of falling: And, Madam, we will add as many as you please to our System for this Night, and take them away by degrees, as you get more Assurance. Really, said she, I do not think they are needful at present; for I feel I have Courage sufficient to turn round. You must go a step further, said I, and you shall turn round with delight; upon this System you will form to your self very pleasant and agreeable Idea's: As for Example; Sometimes I fansie I am hanging in the Air, and that I stay there without moving, while the Earth turns round under me in four and twenty Hours time, and that I see beneath me all those different Faces; some white, some black, some tawny, others of an Olive-colour; first I see Hats, then Turbants, there <IIM>Hands</IIM> cover'd with Wool, there shav'd Heads; sometimes Towns with Steeples, some with their long small-pointed Pyramids, and Half-moons on their tops; sometimes Towns with Porcelane Towers; after them, spacious Fields, without Towns, only Tents and Huts; here vast Seas, frightful Desarts; in short, all the Variety that is to be seen upon the Face of the Earth. Indeed, said she, such a sight wou'd be very well worth twenty four Hours of ones Time: So that by this System, through the same place where we now are (I do not mean this Park, but that space of Air which our Bodies fill) several other Nations must successively pass, and we return hither, in twenty four hours, to our own place again.</P013>

explanations: The Marquise's refusal to speak ("Je ne veux plus vous dire rien") is changed to a more direct refusal to argue ("I will not argue with you"). The nuanced "comme en colere" (as if in anger) is simplified to "angrily," and the sentence structure is inverted for a more direct English flow.

The metaphorical "piroüette aussi legere" (such a light/slight pirouette) becomes the more common and concrete "little Humming-Top." The impersonal "qu'il n'y ait rien à craindre" (that there is nothing to fear) is simplified to the personal "that I am in no danger."

The French subjunctive mood and the nuanced phrase "le moins du monde en peril de se mouvoir" (in the least bit of danger of moving) are simplified. The English uses simple past ("thought"), omits the intensifier "le moins du monde" (rendering it as "any"), and replaces "de se mouvoir" (of moving) with the more concrete "of falling."

The impersonal French "il ne faut point s'épargner... pour dormir en assurance" (one must not spare... to sleep in safety) is simplified. The concise "pour dormir en assurance" is expanded to "to sleep in quiet, without fear of falling," making the reason for assurance explicit and reducing the need for inference.
The explicit verb "oser" (to dare) in "pour oser tourner" (to dare to turn) is omitted in the translation "to turn round," simplifying the expression of the Marquise's volition and courage.

The predictive "Vous irez bien-tost encore plus loin" (You will very soon go even further) is simplified to the more prescriptive and concrete "You must go a step further." Additionally, "des idées réjoüissantes" (joyful/cheering ideas) becomes the more general "very pleasant and agreeable Idea's," simplifying the specific emotional tone.

The phrase "grands Païs qui n'ont que des Cabanes" (large Countries that have only Huts) is simplified to "spacious Fields, without Towns, only Tents and Huts," reducing the geographical scale to a more easily visualized unit.
The adjective "infinie" (infinite) is omitted from "toute cette variesté infinie" (all this infinite variety), reducing the conceptual density and lexical richness of the original.

The abstract "tout cela" (all that) becomes the concrete "such a sight." The French clausal structure "meriteroit bien que l'on donnast [temps] à le voir" (would well deserve that one give [time] to see it) is simplified to the more direct English idiom "[sight] wou'd be very well worth [time]."

The abstract French phrase "à le prendre dans l'air" (taking it/considering it in the air), referring to a location, is made more concrete and explicit as "that space of Air which our Bodies fill," simplifying the concept.

chunks.source_manual: <P014>Copernic, luy répondis-je, ne le comprendroit pas mieux. D'abord il passera par icy des Anglois qui raisonneront peut-estre de quelque dessein de Politique avec moins de gayeté que nous ne raisonnons de nostre Philosophie; ensuite viendra une grànde Mer, & il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau qui n'y sera pas si à son aise que nous. Après cela Paroistront des <IIM>Iroquois</IIM>, qui mangeront tout vif quelque prisonnier de guerre, qui fera semblant de ne s'en pas soucier; des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso, qui n'employeront tout leur temps qu'à préparer le Repas de leurs Maris, & à se peindre de bleu les lévres & les sourcils, pour plaire aux plus <IIM> vilains Hommes du monde</IIM>; des Tartares qui iront fort devotement en Pelerinage vers ce Grand Prestre, qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obscur où il n'est éclairé que par des Lampes, à la lumiere desquelles on l'adore; de belles Circassiennes qui ne feront aucune façon d'accorder tout au premier venu, horsmis ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris; de petits Tartares qui iront voler des Femmes pour les Turcs & pour les <IIM>Persans</IIM>; enfin, nous qui debiterons peut-estre encore des <NCE>resveries</NCE>.</P014>
chunks.target_manual: <P014>Copernicus himself, said I, Madam, did not understand it better. At first will be here the English, discoursing, it may be, upon some politick Design, with more Gravity, but less Pleasure, than we talk of our Philosophy: Next will come a vast Ocean, in which there will be sailing some Ships, perhaps not so much at their Ease as we are: Then will appear the <IIM>Canibals</IIM>, eating some Prisoners of War alive, they seeming very unconcern'd at what they suffer: After them, the Women of the Country of Iesso, who spend all their time in preparing their Husbands Meals, and in painting their Lips and Eye-brows with Blew, to please the ugliest Fellows in the World: Next will succeed the Tartars, who go, with great Devotion, on Pilgrimage to that great Priest, who never comes out of an obscure place, where he has no other Light but Lamps, by which they adore him: After them, the beautiful Circassian Women, who make no difficulty of granting any Favour to the first Comer, except what they essential know does belong to their Husbands: Then the Crim, or Little Tartars, who live by stealing of Wives for the Turks and Persians: And at last, our selves again, perhaps talking as we do now.</P014>

explanations: The French verb "raisonnons" (from "raisonner" - to reason, to discourse logically) implies a more specific and intellectual activity than the common English verb "talk." This substitution simplifies the verb choice, reducing the formality and the specific intellectual connotation of the original expression.

The French impersonal construction 'il se pourra trouver... quelque Vaisseau' (literally 'it will be able to be found... some vessel') describing the presence of ships is rephrased into a more direct and active description 'there will be sailing some Ships.' This simplifies the syntax by moving from an impersonal and somewhat complex formulation to a more vivid and straightforward declarative statement.

The specific ethnonym "Iroquois" is replaced by the generic and sensationalized term "Canibals." This simplifies the cultural reference by substituting a named indigenous group with a generalized category defined by a shocking practice, thereby reducing cultural nuance and historical specificity, possibly to create a more universally understood or sensational image for the contemporary English audience.

The French "qui fera semblant de ne s'en pas soucier" (who will pretend not to care about it) describes a deliberate act of feigning indifference. The English "they seeming very unconcern'd at what they suffer" shifts the focus to the outward appearance ("seeming") and adds an explicit clarification ("at what they suffer," which was implicit). This simplifies the psychological nuance of active pretense to a more direct description of appearance and enhances readability through explicitation.

The French uses the impersonal pronoun "on" in "on l'adore" (meaning "one adores him" or "he is adored"). The English translation replaces this with the explicit subject "they" (presumably referring to the Tartars). This change from an impersonal to a personal construction simplifies the sentence by making the agent clear and direct, reducing a degree of abstractness present in the original.

The French "debiterons... des resveries" (we who will perhaps again be uttering/recounting/peddling daydreams/fantasies) uses the specific verb "débiter" and the nuanced noun "rêveries" (daydreams, musings). The English translation "perhaps talking as we do now" simplifies this to the very general verb "talking" and links it to their current conversation. This results in a loss of lexical richness and the specific, slightly whimsical or self-deprecating tone of the original expression.

chunks.source_manual: <P015>Il est assez plaisant, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, d'imaginer ce que vous venez de me dire; mais si je voyois tout cela d'en haut, je voudrais avoir la liberté de hâter ou d'arrêter le mouvement de la Terre, selon que les objets me plairoient plus ou moins, & je vous assure que je ferais passer bien viste ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique, ou qui mangent leurs Ennemis; mais il y en a d'autres pour qui j'aurois de la curiosité. J'en aurais pour ces Belles Circassiennes, par exemple, elles ont un usage qui me paroist assez particulier. C'est qu'elle sont si belles, luy dis-je, que leurs Maris trovent dans leurs faveurs un superflu qu'ils abandonnent aux Etrangers. Les Femmes de ces Païs-cy sont donc bien laides aux prix d'elles, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, car le Maris ne relâchent rien. Cela est cause qu'on prend davantage, repliquay-je, au lieu que...Taisez-vous, interrompit-elle, je ne veux plus dire de folies, aussi bien il me vient une difficulté sérieuse. Si la Terre tourne, nous changeons d'air à chaque moment, & nous respirons toûjours celuy d'un autre Païs. Nullement, Madame, répondis-je, l'air qui environne la Terre ne s'étend que jusqu'à une certaine hauteur, peut-estre jusqu'à 20 lieües, il nous suit, & tourne avec nous. Vous avez veu mille fois l'ouvrage d'un Ver à Soye, ou ces Coques que ces petits animaux travaillent avec tant d'art pour s'y emprisonner. Elles sont d'une soye fort serrée, mais elles sont couvertes d'un certain duvet fort leger & fort lâche. C'est ainsi que la Terre, qui est assez solide, est couverte depuis sa surface jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus, d'une espece de duvet, qui est l'air, & toute la Coque de Ver à Soye tourne en mesme temps. Au-delà de l'air est la matiere celeste, incomparablement plus pure, plus subtile, & mesme plus agitée que luy.</P015>
chunks.target_manual: <P015>I am mightily taken, said the Marquiese, with the Fancy of what you say; but if I cou'd see all these things from above, I wou'd wish to have the power to hasten and stop the Motion of the Earth, according as I lik'd or dis-lik'd the several Objects that pass under me; I wou'd make the Polititians, and those that eat their Enemies, to move very fast: But there are others that I shou'd be very curious to observe; and particularly, the fine Cercassian Women, who have one so peculiar a Custom. That is, said I, their Husbands, who finding so many Charms in their Embraces, as more than satisfie them, do freely abandon their fair Wives to Strangers. The Women of our Country, said the Marquiese, must be very ugly, if compar'd to the Circassians; for our Husbands will part with nothing. That is the reason, said I, that the more is taken from 'em; whereas - No more of these Fooleries, said the Marquiese, interrupting me; there's a serious Difficulty come into my head: If the Earth turn round, then we change Air every Moment, and must breath still that of another Country. By no means, Madam, said I; the Air which encompasses the Earth extends it self to a certain heighth, it may be, about twenty Leagues, and turns round with us. You have, no doubt, seen a thousand times the business of the Silk-worm, where the Balls which these little Creatures do work with so much Art, for their own Imprisonment, are compact, and wrought together with Silk, which is very closely join'd; but they are cover'd with a kind of Down, that is very light and soft: Thus it is, that the Earth, which is very solid, is wrapp'd in a Covering of soft Down of twenty Leagues thickness, which is the Air that is carried round at the same time with it: Above the Air is that Celestial Matter I spoke of, incomparably more pure, more subtile, and more agitated than the Air.</P015>

explanations: The French phrase "je vous assure que" (I assure you that), an emphatic conversational element present at the beginning of this clause, is omitted in the English translation. This simplifies the sentence by making its structure more direct (beginning with "I wou'd make...") and removing the parenthetical assurance.

The descriptive French clause "ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique" (literally, "those who trouble themselves with/get entangled in Politics") is simplified to the single, common English noun "the Polititians." This reduces syntactic complexity and uses more direct vocabulary.

The abstract French noun "un superflu" (a surplus), which husbands are said to find in their wives' "faveurs" (favors), is rendered as the more explicit and descriptive phrase "so many Charms in their Embraces, as more than satisfie them." This simplifies the original by replacing a condensed, somewhat abstract term with an elaboration using more common vocabulary and concrete imagery, enhancing readability.

The Marquise's French utterance, which includes the direct imperative "Taisez-vous" (Be quiet), the statement "je ne veux plus dire de folies" (I no longer want to say foolish things), and the transitional phrase "aussi bien" (besides/as well), is simplified. The English "No more of these Fooleries" condenses these components into a single, less direct idiomatic phrase, streamlining the expression and omitting the explicit transition.

The detailed French description of the air's extent, "depuis sa surface jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus" (from its surface up to twenty leagues in height at most), is simplified in the English translation. The English effectively reduces this specific part of the description to "of twenty Leagues thickness" (within the larger translated phrase), by omitting the explicit starting point ("depuis sa surface") and rephrasing the complex limit ("jusqu'à... hauteur tout au plus") as a simpler attribute ("thickness"), thereby reducing textual density.

The French text continues its analogy directly: "& toute la Coque de Ver à Soye tourne en mesme temps" (and the whole Silkworm Cocoon turns at the same time). The English translation "that is carried round at the same time with it:" makes the application of this turning motion to the Earth's atmosphere explicit ("that" referring to Air, "it" referring to Earth). This simplifies the text by reducing the inferential leap required from the reader to connect the analogy to the phenomenon being explained.

The French pronoun "luy" (it), referring back to "l'air" (the air), is replaced in the English translation by the explicit noun phrase "the Air." This disambiguation simplifies comprehension by removing the need for the reader to resolve the pronoun reference, thus enhancing clarity.

chunks.source_manual: <P016>Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. C'est pourtant sur cette Coque de Ver à Soye qu'il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres, & qu'il regne de tous costez une si grande agitation. Oüy, répondis-je, & pendant ce temps-là la Nature qui n'entre point en connoissance de tous ces petits mouvemens particuliers, nous emporte tous ensemble d'un mouvement général, & se joüe de la petite boule.</P016> <P017>Il me semble, reprit-elle, qu'il est ridicule d'estre sur quelque chose qui tourne, & de se tourmenter tant; mais le malheur est qu'on n'est pas assez assuré qu'on tourne; car enfin, à ne vous rien celer, toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'apperçoive du mouvement de la Terre, me sont un peu suspectes. Est-il possible qu'il ne laissera pas quelque petite marque sensible à laquelle on le reconnoisse?</P017> <P018>Les mouvemens les plus naturels, répondis-je, & les plus ordinaires sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir, & cela est vray jusque dans la Morale. Le mouvement de l'Amour propre nous est si naturel, que le plus souvent nous ne le sentons pas, & que nous croyons agir par d'autres principes. Ah! vous <IIM>moralisez</IIM>, dit- elle, quand il est question de <RW>Phisique</RW>, cela s'appelle baailler. Retirons-nous, aussi bien en Voila assez pour la premiere fois. Demain nous reviendrons icy, vous avec vos Systêmes, & moy avec mon Ignorance.</P018> <P019>En retournant au Château je luy dis pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes, qu'il y en avoit un troisiéme inventé par Ticho- Brahé qui, voulant absolument que la Terre fust immobile, la plaçoit au centre du Monde, & faisoit tourner autour d'elle le Soleil, autour duquel tournoient toutes les autres Planetes, parce que depuis les nouvelles Découvertes, il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planetes autour de la Terre. Mais la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qui a le discernement vif & prompt, jugea qu'il y avoit trop d'affectation à exempter la Terre de tourner autour du Soleil, puis qu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands Corps; que le Soleil n'estoit plus si propre à tourner autour de la Terre, depuis que toutes les Planetes tournoient autour de luy; que ce Systême ne pouvoit estre propre tout au plus qu'à soûtenir l'Immobilité de la Terre, quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir, & nullement à la persuader; & enfin il fut résolu que nous nous en tiendrions à celuy de Copernic, qui est plus uniforme & plus riant, & n'a aucun mélange de préjugé. En effet la simplicité dont il est, vous persuade, & sa hardiesse vous fait plaisir.</P019>
chunks.target_manual: <P016>You represent the Earth to me, said the Marquiese, as a very contemptible thing, by the despicable Idea's you give me of it: 'Tis, nevertheless, upon this Silk-Worm-Ball, there are perform'd such mighty Works; and where there are such terrible Wars, and such strange Commotions as reign every where. 'Tis certainly true, said I, Madam; while at the same time, Nature, who is not at the pains to consider these Troubles and Commotions, carries us all along together, by a general Motion, and does, as it were, play with this little Globe. It seems to me, said she, that 'tis very ridiculous to inhabit any thing that turns so often, and is so much agitated; and the worst of all is, that we are not assur'd whether we turn round, or not; for, to be plain with you, and that I may keep none of my Doubts from you, I do extreamly suspect, that all the Pre-cautions you can take, will not convince me of the Motion of the Earth: For is it possible, but Nature wou'd have taken care to have given us some sensible Sign, by which we might discover the turning round of so vast a Body? The Motions (answer'd I) which are most natural to remove, are the least perceptible; and which holds true, even in Morality; for the Motion of Self-love is so natural to us, that for the most part we do not feel it, while we believe we act by other Principles. Ah, said she, do you begin to speak of <IIM>Moral</IIM> Philosophy, when the Question is of that which is altogether natural? But I perceive you are sleepy, and begin to yawn; let us therefore retire, for there's enough said for the first Night, to morrow we shall return hither again; you with your Systems, and I with my Ignorance. In returning to the Castle, to make an end of what might be said to Systems, I told her, there was a third Opinion invented by Ticho-brahe, who wou'd have the Earth absolutely immoveable, and plac'd in the Centre of the Universe, and made the Sun to turn round it, as he did the other Planets to turn round the Sun; because, since the new Discoveries, it cou'd not be imagin'd that the other Planets turn'd round the Earth. But my Lady Marquiese, whose Judgment and Understanding is solid and penetrating, found, there was too much Affectation in endeavouring to free the Earth from turning round the Sun, since several other great Bodies cou'd not be exempt from that Labour; and that the Sun was not so proper and fit to turn round the Earth, since the other Planets turn round the Sun; and that this new System was only good to maintain the standing still of the Earth, if one had a mind to undertake that Argument; but 'tis not proper to perswade another to believe it. At last, we resolv'd to hold our selves to the Opinion of Copernicus, which is more uniform, and more agreeable, without the least mixture of Prejudice; and, indeed, its Simplicity and Easiness perswades as much as its Boldness pleases.</P016>

explanations: The formal French "n'entre point en connoissance de" (doesn't become aware of) is rephrased. More significantly, "ces petits mouvemens particuliers" (these small particular movements), referring to human affairs, is rendered as "these Troubles and Commotions." This simplifies the abstract philosophical term into more concrete and commonly understood vocabulary, making the idea more accessible.
The French "le malheur est" (the misfortune is) is replaced by the more common and colloquial English phrase "the worst of all is," simplifying the vocabulary and making it more conversational.

The concise and somewhat literary French phrase "à ne vous rien celer" (to hide nothing from you) is expanded and rephrased using the common idiom "to be plain with you" along with an explicative clause. This explicitation reduces the density of the original, simplifying comprehension.

The original sentence structure, where "precautions... are suspect to me," is simplified by changing it to a more direct assertion "I suspect...". Furthermore, "pour empêcher qu'on ne s'apperçoive du mouvement" (to prevent one from noticing the movement) is simplified to the more direct outcome "will not convince me of the Motion," focusing on the personal impact on the speaker rather than the general act of preventing perception.

The French reflexive "se tourmenter tant" (to torment oneself so much / to worry so much), referring to the people on the turning Earth, is translated as "and is so much agitated," which in the English sentence structure refers to "any thing that turns" (i.e., the Earth itself). This simplifies the original by shifting the focus from the psychological distress of inhabitants to a physical characteristic of the planet.

The abstract French phrasing, where "il" (it, referring to the Earth's movement) is the implicit subject that would leave a mark, is simplified by personifying "Nature" as the agent ("Nature wou'd have taken care to have given us"). This makes the concept more concrete. Additionally, the concise "à laquelle on le reconnoisse" (by which one recognizes it) is expanded to the more explicit "by which we might discover the turning round of so vast a Body," clarifying the object.

The reflexive French construction within "sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir" (are those which make themselves felt the least) is simplified to the more direct and common English adjectival phrase "are the least perceptible," using more standard vocabulary and a simpler grammatical structure.

This translation simplifies in several ways: "vous moralisez" (you are moralizing) is explicated as "do you begin to speak of Moral Philosophy." The specific term "Phisique" (Physics) is replaced with the general phrase "that which is altogether natural." Most notably, the witty metaphor "cela s'appelle baailler" (that's called yawning, i.e., it's boring) is transformed into a literal observation ("I perceive you are sleepy, and begin to yawn") and a resulting suggestion, removing the original's figurative layer.

The formal French idiom "épuiser la matière" (to exhaust the subject) is replaced by the more periphrastic but arguably more common and less academic phrasing "to make an end of what might be said to," simplifying the vocabulary choice.

The complex French "ne pouvoit estre propre tout au plus qu'à" (could at most only be suitable for) is simplified to "was only good to." "L'Immobilité de la Terre" (the Earth's immobility) becomes the more common "the standing still of the Earth." The concise "& nullement à la persuader" (and not at all to persuade of it) is expanded and made more explicit as "but 'tis not proper to perswade another to believe it," clarifying the scope.

The French "plus riant" (literally "more smiling"), used metaphorically for attractiveness or pleasantness, is translated with the more common and less figurative "more agreeable," simplifying the original by choosing a standard adjective over a more poetic one.

"La simplicité dont il est" (its simplicity) is rendered as "its Simplicity and Easiness." Adding "Easiness" makes explicit a potential aspect of "simplicité," simplifying the concept by breaking it down rather than relying on the reader to infer all connotations of the single French word.

chunks.source_manual: <P021>Le lendemain au matin dés que l'on pût entrer dans l'Appartement de la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, j'envoyay sçavoir de ses nouvelles, & luy demander si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant. Elle me fit répondre qu'elle estoit déjà toute accoûtumée à cette allûre de la Terre, & qu'elle avoit passé la nuit aussi tranquillement qu'auroit pû faire Copernic luy-mesme. Quelque temps après il vint chez elle du monde qui y demeura jusqu'au soir, selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne. Encore leur fut-on bien obligé, car la Campagne leur donnoit aussi le droit de pousser leur visite jusqu'au lendemain, s'ils eussent voulu, & ils eurent l'honnesteté de ne le pas faire. Ainsi la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> & moy nous nous retrouvâmes libres le Soir. Nous allâmes encore dans le Parc, & la Conversation ne manqua pas de tourneraussi-tost sur nos Sistêmes. Elle les avoit si bien conceus, qu'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois, & elle voulut que je la menasse a quelque chose de nouveau. Et bien donc, luy dis-je, puis que le Soleil, qui est presentement immobile, a cessé d'estre Planete, & que la Terre qui se meut autour de luy, a commencé d'en estre une, vous ne serez pas si surprise d'entendre dire que la Lune est une Terre comme celle-cy, & qu'apparemment elle est habitée. Je n'ay pourtant jamais oüy parler de la Lune habitée, dit-elle, que comme d'une <IIM>folie & d'une vision</IIM>. C'en est peut-estre une aussi, répondis-je. Je ne prens party dans ces choses-là que comme on en prend dans les Guerres Civiles, où l'incertitude de ce qui peut arriver, fait qu'on entretient toûjours des <IIM>intelligences</IIM> dans le party opposé, & <IIM>qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mesmes</IIM>. Pour moy, quoyque je voye la Lune habitée, je ne laisse pas de vivre civilement avec ceux qui ne le croyent pas, <SC></SC> & je me tiens toûjours en estat de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus; mais en attendant qu'ils ayent sur nous quelque avantage considérable, voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune.</P021> <P022>Suposons qu'il n'y ait jamais eu nul commerce entre <NCE>Paris & Saint-Denis</NCE>, & qu'un Bourgeois de Paris qui ne sera jamais sorty de sa Ville, soit sur les Tours de <NCE>Nostre Dame</NCE>, & voye <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE> de loin, on luy demandera s'il croit que <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE> soit habité <SC>comme Paris</SC>. Il répondra hardiment que non; car, dira- t-il, je voy bien les Habitans de Paris, mais ceux de Saint Denis, je ne les voy point, & on n'en a jamais entendu parler. Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera qu'à la verité quand on est sur les <NCE>Tours de Nostre Dame</NCE>, on ne voit pas les Habitans de Saint Denis, mais que l'éloignement en est cause; que tout ce qu'on peut voir de Saint Denis ressemble fort à Paris: que Saint Denis a des Clochers, des Maisons, des Murailles, & qu'il pourroit bien encore ressembler à Paris pour ce qui est d'estre habité. Tout cela ne gagnera rien sur mon Bourgeois, il s'obstinera toûjours à soûtenir que Saint Denis n'est point habité, puis qu'il n'y voit personne. Nostre Saint Denis c'est la Lune, & chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris, qui n'est jamais sorty de sa Ville.</P022> <P023>Ah! interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous nous faites tort, nous ne sommes point si sots que vostre Bourgeois. Puis qu'il voit que Saint Denis est tout fait comme Paris, il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison pour ne le pas croire habité; mais la Lune n'est point du tout faite comme la Terre. Prenez garde, Madame, repris-je, car s'il faut que la Lune ressemble en tout à la Terre, vous Voila dans l'obligation de croire la Lune habitée. J'avoüe, répondit-elle, qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser, & je vous vois un air de confiance qui me fait déjà peur. Les deux mouvemens de la Terre dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée, me <IIM>rendent timide sur tout le reste</IIM>, mais pourtant seroit-il bien possible que la Terre fût lumineuse comme la Lune? Car il faut cela pour leur ressemblance. Helas! Madame, repliquay-je, estre lumineux n'est pas si grand-chose que vous pensez. Il n'y a que le Soleil en qui cela soit une qualité considérable. Il est lumineux par luy-mesme, & en vertu d'une nature particuliere qu'il a, mais les Planetes n'éclairent que parce qu'elles sont éclairées de luy. Il envoye sa lumiere à la Lune, elle nous la renvoye, & il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumiere du Soleil; il n'y a pas plus loin de la Terre à la Lune, que de la Lune à la Terre.</P023>
chunks.target_manual: <P018>AS soon as one could get into my Lady Marquiese's Apartment, I sent to know how she did, and how she had slept that Night in turning round. She sent me word, that now she was pretty well accustom'd to the Motion of the Earth, and that Copernicus himself cou'd not have rested better that Night than she did. A little after this, there came Company to visit my Lady, which, according to the nauseous Country-fashion, stay'd till the Evening, and yet we thought our selves happy that we were so easily rid of 'em then, since, according to the custom of the Country, they might have prolong'd their Visit till the next Day; but they were so civil, as not to do it; so that Madam the Marquiese and I found our selves at liberty. In the Evening we went again to the Park, and the Conversation began as it ended before, of our System: My Lady Marquiese had comprehended 'em so well, that she wou'd not be at the pains to re-assume any thing of what had pass'd, but press'd me to lead her to something that was new. Well, said I, since the Sun, which is now immoveable, and no longer a Planet; and that the Earth, that moves round the Sun, is now one, be not surpriz'd if I tell you, the Moon is another Earth, and is, by all appearance, inhabited. Said she, I never heard of the Moon's being inhabited, but as a Fable. So it may be still, said I; I concern my self no further in these Matters, than Men use to do in Civil Wars; where the Uncertainty of what may be, makes People still entertain a Correspondence with the adverse Party: As for me, tho' I see the Moon inhabited, I live very civilly with those that do not believe it; and I carry my self so trimmingly, that I may, <UP>upon occasion,</UP> with Honour go over to their side who have the better; but still they gain some considerable Advantage over us. I'll tell you my Reasons that make me take part with the Inhabitants of the Moon: Suppose then, there had never been any Commerce between Paris and St. Denis, and that a Citizen of Paris, who had never been out of that City, shou'd go up to the top of the Steeple of our Lady, and shou'd view St. Denis at a distance, and one shou'd ask him if he believ'd St. Denis to be inhabited; he wou'd answer boldly, Not at all; for (he wou'd say) I see the Inhabitants of Paris, but I do not see those of St. Denis, nor ever heard of 'em. It may be, some body standing by, wou'd represent to him, That it was true, one cou'd not see the Inhabitants of St. Denis from our Lady's Church, but that the distance was the cause of it; yet that all we cou'd see of St. Denis, was very like to Paris; for St. Denis had Steeples, Houses and Walls; and that it might resemble Paris in every thing else, and be inhabited as well as it. All these Arguments wou'd not prevail upon my Citizen; who wou'd continue still obstinate in maintaining, that St. Denis was not inhabited, because he saw none of the People. The Moon is our St. Denis, and we the Citizens of Paris, that never went out of our own Town. Ah, interrupted the Marquiese, you do us wrong; we are not so foolish as your Citizens of Paris: Since he sees that St. Denis is so like to Paris in every thing, he must have lost his Reason, if he did not think it was inhabited: But for the Moon, that's nothing like the Earth. Have a care, Madam, said I, what you say; for if I make it appear, that the Moon is in every thing like the Earth, you are oblig'd to believe that the Moon is inhabited. I acknowledge, said she, if you do that, I must yield; and your Looks are so assur'd, that you frighten me already: The two different Motions of the Earth, which wou'd never have enter'd into my Thoughts, make me very apprehensive of all you say. But is it possible that the Earth can be an enlighten'd Body, as the Moon is? For, to resemble it, it must be so. Alas, Madam, said I, to be enlightned, is not so great a matter as you imagine, and the Sun only is remarkable for that Quality: 'tis he alone that is enlightned of himself, by virtue of his particular Essence; but the other Planets shine only, as being enlightned by the Sun: The Sun communicates his Light to the Moon, which reflects it upon the Earth; as the Earth, without doubt, reflects it back again to the Moon, since the distance from the Moon to the Earth is the same as from the Earth to the Moon.</P018>

explanations: The formal and impersonal French construction "leur fut-on bien obligé" (one was very obliged to them) is rendered into a more personal, colloquial, and direct English expression "we thought our selves happy that we were so easily rid of 'em". The personification in "la Campagne leur donnoit ... le droit" (the Countryside gave them the right) is also simplified to the more standard phrase "according to the custom of the Country". This simplifies the formality and structure of the original.

The French "a commencé d'en estre une" (has begun to be one) implies a process of transition. The English "is now one" simplifies this to a direct statement of current state, reducing the nuance of becoming.

The French impersonal construction "d'entendre dire" (to hear it said) is simplified to a more direct, active, and personal construction "if I tell you". This makes the sentence flow more directly and simplifies the original phrasing.

The original French uses two distinct nouns, "folie" (folly, madness) and "vision" (vision, hallucination), to describe how the idea of an inhabited moon is perceived. The translation simplifies this by using a single, more general term "Fable," reducing the lexical density and the specific connotations of the original pair.

The French original describes two cautious actions taken during civil wars: maintaining contacts ("entretient... des intelligences") and careful dealings with enemies ("a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mesmes"). The translation only renders the first action ("entertain a Correspondence"), omitting the second distinct idea of "ménagemens avec ses Ennemis." This reduces the density and complexity of the philosopher's analogy.

The French "voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté" (here is what put me on the side of) is a presentative construction focusing on the factors. The English "I'll tell you my Reasons that make me take part" is more direct and personal, shifting to the speaker's intention to explain, which simplifies the original's structure and makes the discourse more immediately engaging.

The comparative phrase "comme Paris" (like Paris) is omitted at the end of this specific clause in the English translation. While the context implies this comparison, its explicit removal at this point simplifies the sentence by slightly reducing its informational load.

The French "je voy bien" includes the adverb "bien" (well), which adds a slight emphasis on the clarity or certainty of seeing. The English translation "I see" omits this adverb, making the statement slightly more direct and less emphatic, thereby simplifying the nuance.

The French uses the impersonal pronoun "on" in "on n'en a jamais entendu parler" (one has never heard speak of them). The English translation shifts to an implied personal pronoun "I" ("nor [have I] ever heard of 'em"), making the statement more direct and less formal, which simplifies the sentence structure and voice.

The French phrase "pour ce qui est d'estre habité" (as regards being inhabited / in terms of being inhabited) is somewhat abstract and syntactically dense. The English translation "in every thing else, and be inhabited as well as it" expands and clarifies this idea, breaking it into more concrete and easily digestible components, thus simplifying the original's concise but complex phrasing.

The French "chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris" (each of us is this Citizen of Paris) uses a distributive singular. The English translation "and we the Citizens of Paris" simplifies this to a collective plural ("we," "Citizens"), which is a more general and less granular statement, thereby simplifying the structure of the comparison.

The French "ne...point si sots" (not at all so foolish) uses the strong negation "ne...point." The English "not so foolish" omits the intensifier "at all" (the typical equivalent of "point"), slightly reducing the force of the statement and simplifying the expression. Additionally, "vostre Bourgeois" (your Citizen, singular) is generalized to "your Citizens of Paris" (plural).

The French "pour ne le pas croire habité" (literally 'for not to believe it inhabited', meaning 'for not believing it to be inhabited') uses a negative infinitive phrase to express reason. The English translation changes this to a conditional clause "if he did not think it was inhabited," which simplifies the syntactic structure by making the condition more explicit and arguably more common in English.

The French "n'est point du tout faite comme" (is not at all made like) is a strong negation emphasizing the lack of resemblance in form or nature. The English "that's nothing like" is a more colloquial and very common idiomatic expression that conveys a similar meaning concisely, simplifying the phrasing from a more formal construction.

The French "s'il faut que la Lune ressemble" (if it must be that the Moon resembles / if it is necessary that the Moon resembles) expresses an impersonal necessity or condition. The English translation "if I make it appear, that the Moon is in every thing like the Earth" shifts this to a personal action by the speaker ("if I make it appear"), simplifying the abstract "il faut que" construction into a more direct, agent-focused statement.

The French "vous Voila dans l'obligation" (literally, "there you are in the obligation") is a slightly more dramatic and idiomatic presentative construction. The English "you are oblig'd" is a more standard and direct statement of obligation, simplifying the stylistic flourish of the original.

The French "qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser" (that there will be no way to avoid it/get out of it) is a somewhat formal and impersonal way of stating the consequence. The English "if you do that, I must yield;" simplifies this by using a more direct personal verb ("I must yield") and explicitly linking it with "if you do that" to the philosopher's preceding challenge, making the logical connection clearer and the expression more common.

The French "seroit-il bien possible que..." uses a conditional mood and the intensifier "bien" (indeed/really), conveying tentativeness and emphasis. The English "is it possible that..." shifts to a more direct indicative mood and drops the intensifier, simplifying the modal complexity and making the question more straightforward.

The French "il n'y a pas plus loin... que..." (it is no further... than...) uses a comparative structure expressing equality through a negative limit. The English translation "the distance... is the same as..." rephrases this into a direct statement of equality ("is the same as"), which is a more straightforward and possibly easier syntactic structure for the reader to process.

chunks.source_manual: <P024>Mais, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, la Terre est-elle aussi propre que la Lune à renvoyer la lumiere au Soleil? Je vous vois toûjours pour la Lune, repris-je, un reste d'estime dont vous ne sçauriez vous défaire. La lumiere est composée de petites balles qui bondissent sur ce qui est solide <UP></UP>, & retournent d'un autre costé, au lieu qu'elles passent au travers de ce qui leur presente des ouvertures en ligne droite, comme l'air ou le verre. Ainsi ce qui fait que la Lune nous éclaire, c'est qu'elle est un Corps dur & solide, qui nous renvoye ces petites balles. Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette mesme dureté & cette mesme solidité. Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'estre posté avantageusement. Parce que la Lune est éloignée de nous, nous ne la voyons que comme un Corps lumineux, & nous ignorons que ce soit une grosse masse, toute semblable à la Terre. <IIM>Au contraire,</IIM> parce que la Terre a le malheur que nous la voyons de trop prés, elle ne nous paroist qu'une grosse masse, propre seulement à fournir de la pasture aux Animaux, & nous ne nous apercevons pas qu'elle est lumineuse, faute de nous pouvoir mettre à quelque distance d'elle. Cela va de la mesme maniere, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que quand nous sommes frapez de l'éclat des Conditions élevées au-dessus des nostres, & que nous ne voyons pas qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extremement.</P024> <P025>C'est la mesme chose, répondis-je. Nous voulons juger de tout, & nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe. Nous voulons juger de nous, nous en sommes trop près; nous voulons juger des autres, nous en sommes trop loin. Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir. Il faudroit estre simplement Spectateur du Monde, & non pas Habitant. Je ne me consoleray jamais, dit-elle, de l'injustice que nous faisons à la Terre, & de la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune, si vous ne m'assurez que les Gens de la Lune ne connaissent pas mieux leurs avantages que nous connoissons les nostres, & qu'ils prennent nostre Terre pour un Astre, sans sçavoir que leur habitation en est un aussi. Pour cela, repris-je, je vous le garantis. Nous leur paroissons faire assez regulierement nos fonctions d'Astres. Il est vray qu'ils ne nous voyent pas décrire un Cercle autour d'eux, mais il n'importe, voicy ce que c'est. La moitié de la Lune qui se trouva tournée vers nous au commencement du Monde, y a toûjours esté tournée depuis; elle ne nous presente jamais que ces yeux, cette bouche, & le reste de ce visage que nostre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre. Si l'autre moitié opposée se presentoit à nous, d'autres tâches differemment arrangées, nous feroient sans doute imaginer quelque autre figure. Ce n'est pas que la Lune ne tourne sur elle-mesme, elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois; mais lors qu'elle fait une partie de ce tremblement <RW></RW>, & de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.</P025> <P026>Toutes ces Planetes, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, sont faites comme nous, qui rejettons toûjours sur les autres ce qui est en nous-mesmes. La Terre dit, Ce n'est pas moy qui tourne, c'est le Soleil. La Lune dit, Ce n'est pas moy qui tremble, c'est la Terre. Il y a bien de l'erreur par tout. Je ne vous conseille pas d'entreprendre d'y rien réformer, répondis-je; il vaut mieux que vous acheviez de vous convaincre de l'entiere ressemblance de la Terre & de la Lune. Representez-vous ces deux grandes Boules suspendües dans les Cieux. Vous sçavez que le Soleil éclaire toûjours une moitié des Corps qui sont ronds, & que l'autre moitié est dans l'ombre. Il y a donc toûjours une moitié, tant de la Terre que de la Lune, qui est éclairée du Soleil, c'est à dire, qui a le jour, & une autre moitié qui est dans la nuit. Remarquez d'ailleurs que comme une Balle a moins de force & de vistesse aprés qu'elle a esté donner contre une muraille qui l'a renvoyée d'un autre costé, de mesme la lumiere s'affoiblit lors qu'elle a esté réfléchie par quelque Corps. Cette lumiere blanchâtre qui nous vient de la Lune, est la lumiere mesme du Soleil, mais elle ne peut venir de la Lune à nous que par une réflexion. Elle a donc beaucoup perdu de la force & de la vivacité qu'elle avoit lors qu'elle estoit receüe directement sur la Lune, & cette lumiere éclatante que nous recevons directement du Soleil & que la Terre reflechit sur la Lune, ne doit plus estre qu'une lumiere blanchâtre quand elle y est arrivée. Ainsi ce qui nous paroit lumineux dans la Lune, & qui nous éclaire pendant nos nuits, ce sont des parties de la Lune qui ont le jour, & les parties de la Terre qui ont le jour, lors qu'elles sont tournées vers les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit, les éclairent aussi. Tout dépend de la maniere dont la Lune & la Terre se regardent. Dans les premiers jours du mois que l'on ne voit pas la Lune, c'est qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & qu'elle marche de jour avec le Soleil. Il faut necessairement que toute sa moitié qui a le jour, soit tournée vers le Soleil, & que toute sa moitié qui a la nuit, soit tournée vers nous. Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié qui n'a aucune lumiere pour se faire voir. Mais cette moitié de la Lune qui a la nuit, estant tournée vers la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, nous voit sans estre veüe, & nous voit sous la même figure que nous voyons la Pleine Lune. C'est alors pour les Gens de la Lune Pleine Terre, s'il est permis de parler ainsi. Ensuite la Lune qui avance sur son Cercle d'un mois, se dégage de dessous le Soleil, & commence à tourner vers nous un petit coin de sa moitié éclairée, & voila le Croissant. Alors aussi les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit, commencent à ne plus voir toute la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, & nous sommes en Decours pour elles.</P026>
chunks.target_manual: <P019>But, said the Marquiese, is the Earth as proper for reflecting the Light of the Sun, as the Moon? You are always for the Moon, said I, and you cannot rid your self of those Remains of Kindness you have for her. Light is compos'd for little Balls, which rebound upon any solid Body, <UP>which is opaque, or obscure,</UP> and are sent back another way; whereas they pass through any thing that offers them an Opening, or Passage, in a streight Line; which is Diaphanus, or clear; such as Air and Glass: So that the Moon enlightens us, because she is an Opaque, solid Body, which retorts these little Balls upon us; and I believe you will not dispute the same Solidity to the Earth. Admire then, Madam, how advantageous it is, to be well posted; so that the Moon being at a great distance from us, we see it as an enlightned Body only, but are ignorant that 'tis a gross, solid Mass, very much like the Earth: On the other hand, the Earth having the ill luck to be seen by us too near, we consider it only as a great massy Body, fit only for the producing of Food for living Creatures. 'Tis just, said the Marquiese, as when we are struck and surpriz'd with the Splendour of Quality above our own; we do not perceive, that in the main, there's no difference between them and us. 'Tis just so, said I; and we will needs be judging of every thing; but we have the mis-fortune, still to be plac'd in a false Light: Wou'd we judge of our selves, we are too near; if of others, we are too far off: Cou'd one be plac'd between the Moon and the Earth, that wou'd be a true Station to consider both well: To this End, we ought only to be Spectators of the World, and not Inhabitants. I shall never be satisfy'd, said the Marquiese, with the Injury we do the Earth, in being too favourably engag'd for the Inhabitants of the Moon, unless you can assure me, that they are as ignorant of their Advantages, as we are of ours; and that they take our Earth for a Star, without knowing that the Globe they inhabit is one also. Be assur'd of that, Madam, said I, that the Earth appears to them to perform all the Functions of a Star: 'Tis true, they do not see the Earth describe a Circle round 'em, but that's all one; I'll explain to you what it is: That side of the Moon which was turn'd towards the Earth at the beginning of the World, has continu'd towards the Earth ever since; which still represents to us these same Eyes, Nose and Mouth, which our Imaginations fansie we see compos'd of these Spots, Lights and Shadows, which are the Surface of the Moon: Cou'd we see the other half of the Moon, 'tis possible our Fancy wou'd represent to us some other Figure. This does not argue, but the Moon turns however upon her own Axis, and takes as much time to perform that Revolution, as she does to go round the Earth in a Month. But then, when the Moon performs a part of her Revolutions on her own Axis, and that she ought to hide from us (for Example) one Cheek of this imaginary Face, and appear to us in another Position, she does at the same time perform as much of the Circle she describes in turning round the Earth; and tho' she is in a new Point of Sight or Opposition as to us, yet she represents to us still the same Cheek: So that the Moon, in regard to the Sun, and the other Planets, turns upon her own Axis; but does not so as to the Earth.</P019> <P020>The Inhabitants of the Moon see all the other Planets rise and set in the space of fifteen Days, but they see our Earth always hanging in the same Point of the Heavens. This seeming Immovability does not very well agree with a Body that ought to pass for a Planet; but the truth is, the Earth is not in such perfection: Besides, the Moon has a certain trembling Quality, which does sometimes hide a little of her imaginary Face, and at other times shews a little of her opposite Side; and no doubt but the Inhabitants of the Moon attribute this shaking to the Earth, and believe we make a certain swinging in the Heavens, like the Pendulum of a Clock. All these Planets, said the Marquiese, are like us Mortals, who always cast our own Faults upon others: Says the Earth, It is not I that turn round, 'tis the Sun: Says the Moon, It is not I that tremble, 'tis the Earth: There are Errors and Mistakes every where. I wou'd not advise you, said I, to undertake to reform any of 'em; 'tis better that I make an end in convincing you, that the Moon is in all things like the Earth. Represent to your self these two great Globes, hanging in the Heavens; you know that the Sun does always enlighten one half of any Globe, and the other half is in the Shadow; there is therefore always one half of both Moon and Earth that is enlightned, or half Day, and the other half is still in the Darkness of Night. Be pleas'd, besides, to consider that a Ball has less force and swiftness after it re- bounds from a Wall, against which it was thrown, than it had before it touch'd the Wall, which sends it another way; so Light is not so strong, after 'tis reflected by <IIM>any solid Body</IIM>: This pale Light which comes to us from the Moon, is the Light of the Sun it self, but we have it only by Reflection from the Moon, and has lost a great deal of that Strength and Vivacity which it had when 'twas receiv'd by the Moon, directly from the Sun; and that bright and dazling Light which we receive from the Sun, must in the same manner appear to the Inhabitants of the Moon, after 'tis reflected by the Earth, on the Moon: So that the Surface of the Moon, which we see enlightned, and which shines upon us in the Night, is that half of the Moon that enjoys the Day, as that half of the Globe of the Earth which is enlightned by the Sun, when 'tis turn'd towards the darkened half of the Globe of the Moon, does give Light to the Inhabitants there, during their Nights. All depends upon the different Opposition and Aspects between the Moon and the Earth: The first and second Day of the Moon, we do not see her, because she is betwixt the Sun and us, and moves with the Sun by our Day; it necessarily follows, that the half of the Moon which is enlightned, is turn'd towards the Sun, and the obscure part towards the Earth; 'tis no wonder then, that we cannot see that half which is dark; but that same half of the Moon which is in Darkness, being turn'd towards the enlightned half of the Earth, the Inhabitants see us, without being seen, and the Earth appears to them, as their Full-Moon does to us; and so, if one may use the Expression, 'tis with them Full-Earth. After this, the Moon going on in her Monthly Circle, dis-engages her self from the Sun, and begins to turn towards us a part of her enlightned half, which is the Crescent; at the very same time, the darkned half of the Moon loses some share of the enlightned part of the Earth, and then <NCE>the Earth is in the Wain,</NCE> as to its Inhabitants.</P020>

explanations: The formal French phrasing 'un reste d'estime dont vous ne sçauriez vous défaire' is simplified. 'Dont vous ne sçauriez vous défaire' (of which you would not know how to rid yourself) becomes the more direct 'you cannot rid your self of', and 'estime' (esteem) is rendered as the more common 'Kindness'.

The translation simplifies by omitting one of the two qualities mentioned in the French ('cette mesme dureté & cette mesme solidité' - this same hardness and this same solidity), reducing the description to just 'the same Solidity'.

The French nominal construction 'ce que c'est que d'estre posté avantageusement' (what it is to be advantageously posted) is simplified to the more direct English clausal structure 'how advantageous it is, to be well posted'.

The translation simplifies by omitting the entire final clause of the French sentence ('& nous ne nous apercevons pas qu'elle est lumineuse, faute de nous pouvoir mettre à quelque distance d'elle' - and we do not perceive that it is luminous, for want of being able to put ourselves at some distance from it), reducing the length and density of the original text.

The French 'qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extremement' (that fundamentally they all resemble each other extremely) is simplified to the more direct and common expression 'that in the main, there's no difference between them and us.' The abstract 'Conditions élevées' (elevated conditions) is also simplified to the more concrete 'Quality' (social standing).

The complex French noun phrase 'la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune' (the too favorable preoccupation we have for the Moon) is simplified into the participial construction 'in being too favourably engag'd for the Inhabitants of the Moon.' The word 'consoleray' (console) is translated as 'satisfy'd,' simplifying the emotional nuance.

The French qualifier 'assez regulierement' (quite regularly) is omitted and the idea rendered as 'all the Functions,' simplifying the statement by removing a nuance of degree and making it more absolute.

The translation simplifies by omitting the explicit cause ('d'autres tâches differemment arrangées' - other differently arranged spots) for imagining a different figure. It also weakens the certainty of 'sans doute' (undoubtedly) to ''tis possible.'

The condensed and abstract French phrase regarding the Moon's 'tremblement' and its perceived effect on Earth is replaced by a more explicit and descriptive explanation of libration and how the Moon's inhabitants might misinterpret it, making the concept more accessible by clarifying agency and description.

The French 'qui rejettons toûjours sur les autres ce qui est en nous-mesmes' (who always reject onto others what is in ourselves) is simplified using the more common and idiomatic English expression 'who always cast our own Faults upon others.'

The phrase 'l'entiere ressemblance de la Terre & de la Lune' (the entire resemblance of the Earth & the Moon) is simplified to the more common English phrasing 'that the Moon is in all things like the Earth.'

The French 'la lumiere s'affoiblit' (light weakens) is simplified to the more common 'Light is not so strong.' The English also adds an explicit comparative clause ('than it had before it touch'd the Wall') to the preceding analogy of the ball, clarifying the comparison.
The French 'blanchâtre' (whitish), a specific and less common color descriptor, is simplified to the more common and general English word 'pale.'

The general French 'ce qui nous paroit lumineux dans la Lune' (that which appears luminous to us in the Moon) is rendered more concretely as 'the Surface of the Moon, which we see enlightned.' The second part of the sentence is simplified by the addition of explicit details (e.g., 'half of the Globe of the Earth', 'to the Inhabitants there'), making the complex scenario of reciprocal illumination clearer.

The idiomatic French 'Nous n'avons garde de voir' (We are far from seeing/We certainly don't see) is simplified to the common English phrase ''tis no wonder then, that we cannot see.' Furthermore, 'qui n'a aucune lumiere pour se faire voir' (which has no light to make itself seen) is simplified to the direct 'which is dark.'
The French 'un petit coin de sa moitié éclairée' (a little corner of its lit half), which is more specific and imagistic, is simplified to the more general 'a part of her enlightned half.'

chunks.source_manual: <P027>Il n'en faut pas davantage, dit brusquement la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je sçauray tout le reste quand il me plaira, je n'ai qu'à y penser un moment, & qu'à promener la Lune sur son Cercle d'un mois. Je vois en gennral que dans la Lune ils ont un mois à rebours du nostre, & je gage que quand nous avons pleine Lune, c'est que toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune est tournée vers toute la moitié obscure de la Terre; qu'alors ils ne nous voyent point du tout, & qu'ils content Nouvelle Terre. Je ne voudrois pas qu'il me fust reproché de m'estre fait expliquer tout au long une chose si aisée. Mais les Eclipses comment vont-elles? Il ne tient qu'à vous de le deviner, répondis-je. Quand la Lune est Nouvelle, qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & que toute sa moitié obscure est tournée vers nous qui avons le jour, vous voyez bien que l'ombre de cette moitié obscure se jette vers nous. Si la Lune est justement sous le Soleil, cette ombre nous le cache, & en mesme temps noircit une partie de cette moitié lumineuse de la Terre qui estoit vûë par la moitié obscure de la Lune. Voila donc une Eclipse de Soleil pour nous pendant nostre jour, & une Eclipse de Terre pour la Lune pendant sa nuit. Lors que la Lune est pleine, la Terre est entre elle & le Soleil, & toute la moitié obscure de la Terre est tournée vers toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune. L'ombre de la Terre se jette donc vers la Lune; si elle tombe sur le Corps de la Lune, elle noircit cette moitié lumineuse que nous voyons, & à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour, elle luy dérobe le Soleil. Voila donc une Eclipse de Lune pour nous pendant nostre nuit, & une Eclipse de Soleil pour la Lune pendant le jour dont elle joüissoit. Ce qui fait qu'il n'arrive pas des Eclipses toutes les fois que la Lune est entre le Soleil & la Terre, ou la Terre entre le Soleil & la Lune, c'est que souvent ces trois Corps ne sont pas tres exactement rangez en ligne droite, & que par consequent celuy qui devroit faire l'Eclipse, jette son ombre un peu à costé de celuy qui en devroit estre couvert.</P027>
chunks.target_manual: <P021>Say no more, said the Marquiese, briskly, I shall know all the rest when I please; I need only think a little, and follow the Moon in her Monthly Circle: I see in general, that the Inhabitants of the Moon have their Month, the exact Reverse of ours; and I am perswaded, when 'tis Full-Moon, the enlightned half of it is turn'd towards the obscure part of the Earth, and then they do not see us, but a certain new Earth. I wou'd not have any Body reproach me with the want of so much Sence, as that you need explain so easie a thing to me. But as to the Eclipses, What is the Cause of them? If you do not understand that, said I, 'tis your own fault. When 'tis New Moon, and that she is between the Sun and the Earth, and that all her obscure half is turn'd towards us, who then enjoy the Day, you may see easily, that the Shadow of this darkned half is cast upon the Earth; if the Moon be directly under the Sun, this Shadow hides the Sun from us, and at the same time darkens a part of the enlightened half of the Earth, which was seen by the Inhabitants of the obscure half of the Moon: And this is an Eclipse of the Sun to us, in our Day; and an Eclipse of the Earth to those in the Moon, in their Night. When the Moon is at the Full, the Earth is betwixt her and the Sun, and all the obscure part of the Earth is turn'd towards the enlightned half of the Moon, the Shadow of the Earth is then cast upon the Moon; and if it falls directly on her Surface, it obscures the enlightned half which we see, and hides the Sun from that enlightned part of the Moon that enjoy'd the Day: This is an Eclipse of the Moon to us, during our Night; and an Eclipse of the Sun to them, during their Day. By this Reason, it falls out, that there are not always Eclipses when the Moon interposes between the Sun and the Earth, or the Earth is interjected between the Sun and the Moon; because these three Bodies are not opposite one to another, in a streight Line; and by consequence, that of the three, which ought to make the Eclipse, casts its shadow a little to one side of that which shou'd be eclips'd.</P021>
