explanations: The French phrase "assez bien" (quite well, fairly well), which qualifies the conviction, is omitted in the English translation. This simplifies the statement by making the conviction more absolute and direct, reducing a layer of nuance.

The phrase "je voy bien que" (I see well that) is simplified to the more direct and common "I know." The metaphorical "ennemie des repetitions" (enemy of repetitions) is simplified to the plainer "does not love Repetitions." The future perfect tense "les aura tous faits différens" (will have made them all different), suggesting a presumed action by Nature, is simplified to a logical deduction "they must all be different," which alters the modality and simplifies the tense structure.

The abstract philosophical statement "Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter" (It is not for the imagination to claim/attempt to represent it) is simplified to a more direct assertion of inability, "Our Imaginations can never comprehend this variety." Furthermore, the original's descriptive limitation of imagination, "elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux" (it is not suited to go further than the eyes), is transformed into a practical, imperative suggestion, "let us be satisfied with our Eyes," simplifying the philosophical reflection into a piece of advice.

"On peut seulement apercevoir" (one can only perceive/glimpse) is strengthened to "we may easily conceive," making the action seem less restrictive and more attainable. The qualifier "certaine" (certain) in "d'une certaine veuë universelle" is dropped, simplifying the phrase to "an universal view." The complex modal structure "doit avoir mise" (must have put/placed), which indicates a strong inference about a past action of Nature, is simplified to the more direct past tense "has form'd." The scope is also reduced from "tous ces Mondes" (all these Worlds) to "the several Worlds."

The French "il faudroit encore trouver" (one would still need to find / it would still be necessary to find) implies an ongoing process or a yet-to-be-defined categorization. The English translation simplifies this by changing the modality to a statement of an existing observed fact ("Nay, there is..."), thereby removing the nuance of a quest for definition or further discovery.

The original French rhetorical question "Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature" (What secret must Nature have had) is simplified by transforming it into an exclamation of wonder: "Yet it is wonderful to observe." The complex modal verb phrase "doit avoir eu" (must have had) is omitted. The general phrase "en tant de manieres" (in so many ways) is replaced by the more concrete, emphatic, and arguably hyperbolic "how many Millions of Times," simplifying the abstract notion of numerousness into a vivid, easily grasped image.

The general pronoun "Nous" (We) is explicitly defined as "We, the Inhabitants of the Earth." This clarification, while adding words, simplifies by removing potential ambiguity for the reader. The specific phrase "dont tous les visages se ressemblent" (all of whose faces resemble each other) is simplified to the more general statement "we resemble one another," shifting the focus from the particular (faces) to the general (we).

The French conditional conclusion "remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisions" (would indeed notice that they would be from two closer/more neighboring worlds) is simplified. The English rephrases this more directly as "he wou'd perceive less difference between them." This replaces a somewhat metaphorical and spatial concept ("closer worlds") with a straightforward comparative statement ("less difference"), simplifying the expression of the idea.

The general adverbs of place "ailleurs" (elsewhere) and "plus loin" (further away) are simplified. "Ailleurs" becomes the more concrete "in another Planet," and "plus loin" is reduced to "In another," losing the specific indication of increasing distance. The impersonal pronoun "on" (one) is replaced by the more specific "they" or "the Inhabitants," simplifying by making the agent explicit.
The adjective "naturel" (natural) qualifying "Sens" (Sense) is omitted in the English translation. This simplifies the description of the sixth sense by removing a specifying detail.

The French states "Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde" (This sixth Sense is apparently in some other World). The English shifts the focus and structure to "It may be the Inhabitants of some other Planet have this advantage." This simplifies by concretizing the abstract idea of a sense existing in a world to inhabitants possessing an "advantage" (the sense). "Quelque autre Monde" (some other World) is also specified to "some other Planet."

The complex French phrase "dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planetes" (in the sharing that we have made with the Inhabitants of other Planets), which implies an active human role in a cosmic distribution, is entirely omitted in the English. This significantly simplifies the concept by removing the notion of human agency in this "sharing." Additionally, the reason "faute d'en connoistre d'autres" (for lack of knowing others) is condensed to the more idiomatic and simpler English phrase "because we know no better."

"Nos Sciences" (Our Sciences, i.e., specific fields of knowledge) is simplified to the more general term "Our Knowledge." The active and sudden failure expressed by "elles nous manquent tout à coup" (they [sciences] fail us suddenly) is rephrased into the more static state "our Ingenuity is at a stand." This simplifies the dynamic action into a more passive condition.

The phrase "quelque chose de ce que nous sçavons" (something of what we know) is rendered as "some things, that are familiar to us." The vocabulary is simplified by using the more common term "familiar to us" instead of a direct translation of "ce que nous sçavons."

The French "les douceurs de l'Amour" (the sweetnesses/delights of Love, plural) is simplified to "the Pleasure of Love" (singular), using a more common and less nuanced term. The intensifier "toûjours" (always) in "toûjours desolée" (always desolated) is omitted. "Les fureurs de la Guerre" (the furies/ragings of War, plural) is simplified to "the fury of War" (singular). These changes reduce lexical richness and intensity for conciseness.

"Paix éternelle" (eternal Peace) is slightly weakened to "constant Peace," a more common adjective. The stark statement "on ne connoist point l'Amour" (one does not know Love at all) is softened and rephrased as lacking "the delights of Love." The simple and direct French statement of state "& on s'ennuye" (and one gets bored/is bored) is expanded into an explicit consequence: "which must render their Lives very irksom." This simplifies the reader's task of inferring the impact of boredom by stating the deduced outcome directly, though it makes the translated phrase longer.

The abstract French phrase "pratique ... pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens" (practices ... for the distribution of happiness or talents) is simplified by replacing it with concrete examples: "by making some happy, others miserable." The future perfect tense "elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué" (she will undoubtedly have practiced it), which conveys strong conviction about a general truth or a past action viewed as completed, is simplified to the present perfect "Nature has done." This change reduces some of the modal force and temporal nuance of the original.

The future perfect tense "elle se sera bien souvenuë" (she will have well remembered) is simplified to the present perfect "she has never forgot," changing the tense and the affirmative emphasis to a negative one. The phrase "ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a" (this marvelous secret that she has) is simplified to "her admirable Art," replacing a slightly more mystical or evocative term with a more common one. The dense French "& de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations" (and of equalizing them at the same time by/through compensations) is significantly expanded and clarified to "tho she has made some equal in some respects, by compensating the want of any one thing, with another of equal value." This elaboration simplifies the original's condensed and potentially ambiguous phrasing by making the mechanism of equalization through compensation explicit and easier for the reader to understand, thus reducing cognitive load.

chunks.source_manual: <P053>Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.</P053>
chunks.target_manual: <P039>Are you satisfi'd, said I, Madam, very gravely; have not I told you Chimeras in abundance? Truly, I find not so much difficulty to comprehend these differences of Worlds; my Imagination is working upon the Model you have given me And I am representing to my own Mind odd Characters and Customs for these Inhabitants of the other Planets. Nay more, I am forming extravagant shapes and figures for 'em: I can describe 'em to you; for I fansie I see 'em here. I leave these shapes, said I, Madam, to entertain you in Dreams this Night, to morrow, we shall know, if they have assisted you, to describe the Inhabitants of some other Planet.</P039>
source_segments: Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux?
Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres?
Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes.
Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres.
Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit.
Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.
target_segments: Are you satisfi'd, said I, Madam, very gravely;
have not I told you Chimeras in abundance?
Truly, I find not so much difficulty to comprehend these differences of Worlds;
And I am representing to my own Mind odd Characters and Customs for these Inhabitants of the other Planets. Nay more, I am forming extravagant shapes and figures for 'em:
I leave these shapes, said I, Madam, to entertain you in Dreams this Night,
to morrow, we shall know, if they have assisted you, to describe the Inhabitants of some other Planet.
explanations: The French participial phrase "en quittant le ton serieux" (leaving/while quitting the serious tone), which describes a dynamic change in the speaker's manner, is translated using the simpler and more static adverbial phrase "very gravely." This simplification reduces the nuance of a transition in tone to a direct description of demeanor.

The French verb "dubité" (likely a manuscript variant or typo for "débité," meaning to reel off, to spout, or to present at length) is translated with the more general and common English verb "told." This choice simplifies the vocabulary by using a less specific verb, thereby losing the particular nuance of "débiter" which can imply a continuous flow or recital of words.

The French clause "il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper..." (it seems to me that I presently have less difficulty in grasping...) is simplified in the translation. The subjective framing "il me semble que" (it seems to me that) is made more direct as "I find." Additionally, the temporal adverb "presentement" (presently) is omitted, reducing a detail and thereby the density of the text, making the Marquise's statement more assertive and less qualified.

This sentence translation shows multiple simplification strategies: 1. The French qualifying phrase "comme je puis" (as I can / as best I can), which adds a layer of meaning about the effort or limitation in the act of imagining, is omitted. 2. The vocabulary is simplified by translating "extraordinaire" (extraordinary, unusual) to the more common and less formal "odd." 3. The single French sentence, which connects two related ideas about imagination with "& je leur compose mesme..." (and I even compose for them...), is restructured. The English uses "Nay more," to introduce the second idea, creating a more distinct separation between the thoughts, which can simplify comprehension by breaking down the compound statement.

The French construction "je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin..." (I advise you to leave the care/task of it...) describes an act of giving advice. The translation changes this to a more direct statement by the philosopher, "I leave these shapes...", which simplifies the interaction from an act of counsel to a more direct action. The somewhat abstract French noun phrase "le soin" (the care, the responsibility, the task) is also replaced by the more concrete purpose "to entertain you," simplifying the expressed thought.

The French sentence structure features two parallel conditional clauses linked by "&": "s'ils vous auront bien servie" (if they will have served you well) AND "s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants..." (if they will have taught you how the inhabitants are made/what they are like). The translation simplifies this compound conditional structure by reducing it to a single conditional clause ("if they have assisted you") followed by an infinitive of purpose ("to describe..."). This merges two distinct potential outcomes into one, thereby reducing syntactic complexity and the density of information regarding the dreams' effects.

chunks.source_manual: <P054>QUATRIEME SOIR.</P054>
chunks.target_manual: <P040>The Fourth Night.</P040>

chunks.source_manual: <P055><SC>Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.</SC> Nous en estions à Venus. On est bien seur, dis-je à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, <SC>mais on ne sçait pas bien en quel temps</SC>, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années, elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroist une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy; & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, elle paroist dedans Venus à peu prés de la mesme grandeur dont Venus nous paroist d'icy.</P055>
chunks.target_manual: <P041>THe Dreams <UP>of my Lady Marquiese</UP> were not lucky, they still represented to her something like what we see on Earth; so that I had as much reason to reproach her, as certain People have to blame us when they see some of our Pictures; for they being ignorant of drawing, and designing, and pleasing themselves with their extravagant and grotesque Figures, tell us, our Pictures are nothing but Men and Women, and that there is no Fancy in 'em; there was therefore a necessity of laying aside all sorts of the Forms and Figures of those Animals that inhabit several Planets, and to rest satisfy'd by guessing as well as we can, in pursuing our Journey, which we had begun, through the several Worlds of the Universe.</P041> <P042>We were at Venus: And there is no doubt, said I to my Lady Marquiese, but Venus turns upon her own Axis, but 'tis not known in what time, and by consequence, we know not the length of her Days, but her Years must consist but of eight Months, since Venus turns round the Sun <UP>in that space of time</UP>. As Venus is forty times less than the Earth, the Earth must necessarily appear to the Inhabitants of Venus, to be forty times bigger than Venus appears to us; and as the Moon is also forty times less than the Earth, by consequence, it must appear to the Inhabitants of Venus, about the same bigness that Venus appears to us.</P042>

explanations: The original French sentence features a complex embedded structure where the object of 'reprocher' (reproach) is a clause itself containing a description of 'certains Peuples' and their artistic habits ('qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques'). The English translation simplifies this syntactic complexity. It presents the comparison more directly ('as certain People have to blame us') and then moves the descriptive details about these 'Peuples' and their art into a subsequent, less syntactically embedded participial phrase ('for they being... grotesque Figures'). The phrase 'à la veüe de nos Tableaux' (at the sight of our paintings) is also rendered with a simpler temporal clause 'when they see some of our Pictures.'

The French interjection "Bon," (meaning "Well," or "Good," and indicating a certain dismissive or matter-of-fact tone from the speakers) is omitted in the English translation. This simplifies the utterance by removing a nuance-carrying discourse marker, making the reported speech more direct.

The French "Habitans de toutes ces Planetes" (the inhabitants of all these planets) is changed to "Animals that inhabit several Planets." The change from "Habitans" (inhabitants, which could include rational beings) to the more restrictive "Animals" narrows the meaning. More significantly, "toutes ces Planetes" (all these planets) is reduced in scope to "several Planets." This lessens the definitiveness and comprehensiveness of the original statement, simplifying the claim by making it vaguer and less sweeping.

The French phrase "Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer..." (It was therefore necessary to resolve to ignore/remain ignorant of...) uses an impersonal verb ("Il falut") followed by a reflexive verb ("se resoudre à" + infinitive). The English "there was therefore a necessity of laying aside..." simplifies this complex verbal construction by opting for an existential phrase ("there was a necessity") followed by a prepositional phrase with a gerund ("of laying aside"). This transformation makes the structure less verb-centric and avoids the French reflexive, simplifying the syntax.

The French "Nous en estions à Venus" uses the pronominal adverb "en" (here meaning roughly "at that point in our discussion/journey concerning"). The English translation "We were at Venus" simplifies this by omitting the nuance carried by "en," resulting in a more direct statement and reducing the idiomatic load for an English reader.

The French "on ne sçait pas bien" means "one does not know well" or "it is not well known," indicating a degree of uncertainty or imprecision. The English "'tis not known" simplifies this by omitting the qualifier "bien" (well). This makes the statement of ignorance more direct and absolute, rather than nuanced.

The French "Pour ses années..." ("As for her years...") uses a common topicalizing construction to introduce the new information about Venus's years. The English translation integrates this more directly into the preceding discourse with "but her Years...", avoiding the distinct introductory phrase. This makes the sentence flow more continuously and arguably simpler in structure by not having a marked topic shift.

The French phrase "de dedans Venus" (literally "from inside Venus") is a concise and somewhat idiomatic way to express "from the perspective of Venus." The English translation "to the Inhabitants of Venus" makes this explicit by specifying who is doing the perceiving. This clarification, while adding words, simplifies the interpretative step for the reader by directly stating the viewpoint.

The French construction "que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy" includes an expletive "ne" (a non-negative "ne") which is a feature of formal French comparative clauses. The English translation "than Venus appears to us" omits this expletive "ne," which has no grammatical function in English and would be confusing. This removal simplifies the clause by conforming to standard English grammar and eliminating a French-specific grammatical particle that adds no meaning for the English reader.

The concise French "dedans Venus" (from Venus's perspective) is rendered as the more explicit "to the Inhabitants of Venus," simplifying by clarification. Additionally, the translator adds "by consequence," which makes the logical connection more explicit than the simple conjunction "&" (and implied) in the French, thus guiding the reader more directly. The vocabulary shift from "grandeur" (size/greatness) to "bigness" is also a move towards a more common, less Latinate term, simplifying vocabulary.

chunks.source_manual: <P056>Vous m'affligez, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroist trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroist de la mesme grandeur dont Vénus nous paroist d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y estre Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger <NCE></NCE>. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une petite Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. <UP></UP> C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Venus; ces Gens là doivent bien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Venus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. <UP></UP> Le climat est tres-favorable aux Amours. Venus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.</P056> <P057>Je vois presentement, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, comment sont faits les Habitans de Venus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, repliquay-je, que vous ne connoissez guere bien les Habitans de Venus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient esté auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.</P057>
chunks.target_manual: <P043>You afflict me, said the Marquiese <UP>, extremely</UP>; I see very well, that our Earth is not <IIM>that happy Planet to the Inhabitants of</IIM> Venus, as she is to us; for our Globe of the Earth must appear too big to the Inhabitants of Venus, to be the <IIM>Fountain</IIM> of Love, but the Moon, which appears to the World of Venus, of the same size that Venus appears to us, is exactly cut out to be <UP>the Source of their Amours, and the lucky Star of their Intrigues</UP>; which Titles are most agreeable to the pretty, clear, twinkling Planets, which have in 'em a certain Air of Gallantry. 'Tis certainly a happy Fate for our Moon to give Laws to the Loves of the Inhabitants of Venus: No doubt, but these People are very soft, and have the Art to please extreamly well. Without dispute, Madam, said I; the very Mobile of Venus are all made up of Celladons and Silvanders, and their most ordinary Conversations excel the finest in Clelia; the Climate being more savourable to Love: Venus being nearer the Sun than we, receives from its Influence a brighter Light, and a more enlivening Heat. I perceive very well, interrupted the Marquiese, what kind of People the Inhabitants of Venus are; they are, like our Moors of Granada, a sort of little Sun-burnt Gentlemen, always in Love, full of Life and Fire, given to making Verses, and great Lovers of Musick, and every Day inventing Feasts, Balls and Masquerades, to entertain their Mistresses. Pray, Madam, said I, you are very ill acquainted with the Inhabitants of Venus; for our Moors of Granada are, in respect to them, as the Inhabitants of Lapland, or Greenland, for Coldness and Stupidity.</P043>

explanations: The translator replaces the specific, poetic French appellations "l'Etoile du Berger" (the Shepherd's Star) and "la Mere des Amours" (the Mother of Loves), rich in cultural allusion, with the more generic "that happy Planet." This simplifies by removing nuanced literary references, improving accessibility but reducing richness.

"Mere des Amours" (Mother of Loves) becomes "Source of their Amours," using more common vocabulary. "Etoile du Berger" (Shepherd's Star) is changed to "the lucky Star of their Intrigues," an interpretative expansion that makes the implied romantic/guiding function explicit, simplifying the original's figurative language.

The concise French idiom "doivent bien entendre la galanterie" (they must be experts in gallantry) is explicated into "are very soft, and have the Art to please extreamly well." This simplifies by breaking down an abstract concept into more concrete, common descriptive terms.

The French pronoun "en" (from it/therefrom), implying the Sun as the source of light and heat, is made explicit in the English translation with "from its Influence." This explicitation simplifies the text by removing the need for a minor inference, clarifying the causal link.

The phrase "un petit Peuple noir" (a small, black People) is translated as "a sort of little Sun-burnt Gentlemen." This simplifies by altering the description: "noir" (black) is replaced by the less direct "Sun-burnt," and "Peuple" (People) is elevated to "Gentlemen," making the image more conventional and less stark.

The translation replaces "Tournois" (Tournaments), a specific term for chivalric contests, with "Masquerades," a more common and contemporary (for the translator's era) form of entertainment, simplifying vocabulary. The added clause "to entertain their Mistresses" further explicates purpose, simplifying by making an implied motivation explicit.

The polite French structure including "Permettez-moy de vous dire" and the nuanced "vous ne connoissez guere bien" (you hardly know well) is simplified. "Pray" conveys politeness, while "you are very ill acquainted" is a more direct, idiomatic, and emphatic English equivalent for the latter part, enhancing straightforwardness.

The French conditional perfect "n'auroient esté...que" (would have been only...), implying a softened or hypothetical comparison, is simplified to the simple present indicative "are...as." This change makes the comparison more direct and assertive, removing modal nuance and thereby simplifying the sentence's illocutionary force.

chunks.source_manual: <P058>Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. <UP></UP> Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de memoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvemens subits, & <IIM>qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.</IIM> <NCE></NCE> Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoye une lumiere si forte, que s'ils estoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de <IIM>tres-foibles</IIM> Crepuscules, & peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un <RW>grand poêle ardent</RW>, peu éloigné de leurs testes, & qui va d'une rapidité prodigieuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent aprés la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Venus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroistre assez grandes. Pour les autres Planetes, comme elles sont au-delà de la <IIM>Terre vers le Firmament</IIM>, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumiere, peut-estre n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien fàché de voir cette <RW>grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient</RW>, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. <SC></SC>.</P058>
chunks.target_manual: <P044>But what then must the Inhabitants of Mercury be, for they are yet more near to the Sun? They must certainly be mad, by having too much Light and Fire; and I believe they have no more Memory, than the most part of our Negroes; they never think, and are void of all Reflection, and they only act by Chance, and by sudden Impulses. In short, the Planet Mercury <IIM>must certainly be the Bethlem</IIM> of the Universe; they see the Sun a great deal bigger than we do, because they are so much nearer to it; he darts upon 'em so strong a Light, that if the Inhabitants of Venus were here, they wou'd take our finest Days for the Remains of a <IIM>saint</IIM> Twi-light; and it may be, the Light we enjoy, wou'd not serve them to distinguish one Object from another; and the Heat they are accustom'd to is so excessive, that the greatest warmth enjoy'd by the Inhabitants of the middle of Africk, wou'd frieze them to death. Their Year casts but three Months; the length of their Day is yet unknown, Mercury being so little a Planet, and so near the Sun, in whose Rays he is so continually lost, that he is hitherto scarce discoverable by <RW>the Art and Skill of</RW> Astronomers, who cou'd never yet get so much hold of Mercury, as to observe the Time in which he performs his Revolution <RW>upon his own Axis</RW> or Centre; but the smallness <UP>of his Planet</UP> perswades me 'tis in a very short time, and then, by consequence, his Days are very short, and his Inhabitants must see the Sun <RW>as a very great flaming Brasier</RW>, very near their Heads, which, to their Apprehension, moves with wonderful Rapidity; this makes them so earnestly wish for the coming Night, which, no doubt, must be much more grateful to 'em than the Day; and during those cooler Hours, they are enlightned by Venus, and by the Earth; which two Planets must appear to them of considerable bigness. As for the other Planets, since they are remov'd further than <IIM>Mercury </IIM>, towards the Firmament, his Inhabitants must see them less than they appear to us, and receive but little Light from 'em, it may be, none at all; the fixed Stars must appear less to 'em also, and they lose the sight of some of 'em entirely, which, in my Opinion, is a very great Loss; for I shou'd be very sorry to see <RW>the vast arch'd Roof of the Heavens</RW> adorn'd with fewer Stars, or those I do see, appear less, and not so bright.</P044>

The concise French 'n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets' (they might not be able to distinguish objects there/in it) implies the medium and nature of objects. The English translation makes these implicit elements explicit ('the Light we enjoy,' 'one Object from another'), simplifying comprehension by reducing the reader's need for inference about how visibility is impaired.

The subtle French statement 'Cela en est mieux pour eux' (That is all the better for them) is replaced with a more direct assertion of consequence. The translator further simplifies by adding an explanatory clause 'which, no doubt, must be much more grateful to 'em than the Day,' making the implicit reasoning for desiring night explicit and easier for the reader to follow.

The generic French temporal phrase 'pendant ce temps-là' (during that time) is translated with the more descriptive 'during those cooler Hours.' This change makes an inferred quality of the time period (night's coolness) explicit, simplifying comprehension by integrating contextual understanding directly into the phrase.

The French phrase uses a conditional mood ('resteroient' - would remain) and a somewhat literary term ('d'une couleur plus effacée' - of a more faded/erased color). The translation simplifies this by using a more direct present indicative mood ('do see') and more common, straightforward vocabulary ('not so bright') to describe the diminished appearance of the stars.

chunks.source_manual: <P059>Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, de cette perte-là que sont les <IIM>Habitans de Mercure</IIM>, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de la chaleur. Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu. Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraischissent, comme on dit qu'il en tombe icy dans les Pays chauds pendant des quatre mois entiers, justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes.</P059> <P060>Cela se peut, repris-je, & mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon. Il y a des Pays dans la Chine qui doivent estre tres-chauds par leur situation, & où il fait pourtant de grands froids pendant les mois de Juillet & d'Aoust, jusque-là que les Rivieres se gelent. C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance. Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM>, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire. Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre, & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement. Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM> & des pluyes.</P060>
chunks.target_manual: <P045>I am not so much concern'd for that Loss, said the Marquiese, as for <IIM>their</IIM> being so extreamly incommoded with excessive Heat; and I wish with all my heart, we cou'd ease 'em of that Trouble. Let us therefore allow 'em long and continued Rain, to refresh 'em; such as are in some of the hot Countries of our Earth, which fall for four Months together, during the hottest Seasons. That may be done, said I; but we may find out another Remedy, to relieve the Inhabitants of Mercury; for there are Countries in China, which, by their Situation, must be very hot; yet notwithstanding, the Cold is so excessive during the Months of Iuly and August, that the Rivers are frozen: The Reason is, These Climates abound with <IIM>Salt-Petre </IIM> (whose Exhalations being very cold) the force of the Heat draws out of the Earth in great abundance. Let us therefore suppose Mercury to be a little Planet, made of <IIM>Salt-Petre </IIM>; and let the Sun extract out of himself a Remedy to his Disease which he gives to the Inhabitants. This is certain, that Nature produces no Animal, but in places where they may live; and Custom and Use, joined with Ignorance of what is better, supplieth all Defects, and makes Life agreeable; for ought we know, the Inhabitants of Mercury want neither Rain, nor Exhalations of <IIM>Salt-Petre</IIM>.</P045>

explanations: The complex French comparative construction 'Je ne suis pas si A (que sont B), que de C' is simplified. The clause 'que sont les Habitans de Mercure,' which specifies that the inhabitants experience the first element of the comparison (the loss), is effectively omitted in the English structure 'I am not so much A, as for C.' This streamlines the sentence by making the reference to the inhabitants' experience of the loss implicit, thus simplifying the syntactic structure of the comparison.

The French phrase 'comme on dit' (as they say/it is said), which prefaces the description of rains, introduces a nuance of reported information or common belief. The English translation 'such as are...' presents this information more directly as a factual example, omitting the indirectness. This simplification removes a layer of attribution, making the statement more assertive.

The French adverb 'justement' (precisely, exactly) is omitted in the English translation. This reduces the emphasis on the timing of the rains, simplifying the description by removing a specific qualifier and slightly reducing the density of the text.

The French 'rafraîchir... Mercure d'une autre façon' (cool Mercury in another way) is rendered more explicitly and goal-oriented as 'find out another Remedy, to relieve the Inhabitants of Mercury.' The translation simplifies the concept by shifting from the action on the planet ('rafraîchir Mercure') to the direct benefit for its inhabitants ('relieve the Inhabitants') and by using the more concrete 'Remedy' instead of the general 'façon' (way), making the philosopher's intention clearer and more accessible.

The French 'survient' (intervenes/arises), describing how habit and ignorance operate, is a single, somewhat abstract verb. The English 'supplieth all Defects' explicates the *mechanism* by which habit and ignorance lead to an agreeable life, making the concept less abstract and easier to grasp. Additionally, the specific 'les y fait vivre agréablement' (makes *them* live *there* agreeably) is generalized to 'makes Life agreeable,' simplifying the statement by removing specific referents.

The French 'Ainsi on pourroit même se passer...' (Thus one could even do without...) presents a fairly direct logical deduction. The English translation softens this assertion by adding 'for ought we know,' reframing it as a more tentative speculation, which can make the idea more accessible to a general reader. Furthermore, the impersonal 'on pourroit se passer de' (one could do without) is changed to a more direct statement about 'the Inhabitants of Mercury want neither...', focusing on the beings rather than an abstract possibility. The specification 'Exhalations of Salt-Petre' for 'Salpêtre' also clarifies the concept by linking to the earlier discussion, aiding comprehension.

chunks.source_manual: <P061>Aprés Mercure vous sçavez qu'on trouve le Soleil. Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans. Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là. Nous jugeons par la Terre qui est habitée, que les autres Corps de la mesme espece qu'elle, doivent l'estre aussi; mais le Soleil n'est point un Corps de la mesme espece que la Terre, ny que les autres Planetes. Il est la source de toute cette lumiere que les Planetes ne font que se renvoyer les unes aux autres, aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy. Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles, mais elles ne la peuvent produire. Luy seul tire de soy-mesme cette pretieuse substance; il la pousse avec force de tous costez; de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide, & d'une Planete à l'autre il s'épand de longues & vastes traisnées de lumieres qui se croisent & se traversent, & s'entrelassent en mille façons diferentes, & forment d'admirables tissus de la plus riche matiere qui soit au monde. Aussi le Soleil est-il placé dans le centre, qui est le lieu le plus commode d'où il la puisse distribuer également, & animer tout par sa chaleur <NCP></NCP>. Le Soleil est donc un Corps <UP>particulier</UP>, mais quelle sorte de Corps? On est bien embarrassé à le dire. On avoit toûjours crû que c'estoit un feu tres-pur, mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce <IIM>Siecle</IIM>, qu'on apperceut des taches sur sa surface. Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le <IIM>Monde Philosophe</IIM> n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient; <UP>qu'elles avoyent un mouvement autour du Soleil</UP>, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous. Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...</P061>
chunks.target_manual: <P046>After Mercury, you know, the next Planet we find in our Journey, is the Sun; and if we judge by the Earth <NCP>(which is inhabited)</NCP> that other Bodies of the same kind may be so too, we are mistaken, and the Why not will fail us here; for the Sun is a Body of a quite different Nature from the Earth, and other Planets: He is the Source and Fountain of all that Light, which the other Planets do only reflect from one to another, after having receiv'd it from him; and so they can exchange Light one with another, but are incapable of producing it: The Sun alone draws from it self this precious Substance, which he darts a-round him with great Force and Violence, and which is intercepted by every Body that is solid; so that there is reflected from one Planet to another long streams and streaks of Light, which crossing and traversing each other in the Air, are interwoven a thousand different Ways, and so form a Mixture of the richest substance in Nature: For this end the Sun is plac'd in the Centre, which is the Situation most proper and commode; from whence he may equally dispense and distribute his Light and Heat, for the livening and enlightning all things round him. The Sun is therefore a Body of a particular Substance; but what kind of Body, or what kind of Substance, is all the difficulty: Heretofore 'twas believ'd, that the Sun was a pure Fire; but the Error of this Opinion was found out in the Beginning of this Age, by Spots which were discover'd upon the Surface of the Sun; as a little after that time, there were new Planets discover'd, of which I shall speak hereafter: The learned part of the World were full of nothing else but these new Planets; and Discourses of 'em were so much in fashion, that they believ'd the Spots in the Sun were nothing else but these new Planets, moving round 'em, which necessarily hid a part of his Body from our sight, when their obscure Side was turn'd towards us. The learned Men of the World made their Court to most Kings and Princes, with these new discover'd Planets; giving the Name of one Prince to one, and of another Prince to another; so that they were like to quarrel, to whom they shou'd belong.</P046>

explanations: The French text presents a sequence of distinct statements regarding the sun's uninhabitability and the reasoning behind it. The English translation simplifies this by restructuring these points into a single, more explicitly connected conditional clause ('if we judge... we are mistaken...'). This makes the logical argument more overt and guided, omitting the direct, stark assertion 'Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans' (There is no way to put inhabitants there).

The French 'pour ainsi dire' (so to speak) adds a conversational nuance, qualifying the 'exchanges' of light. The English 'and so' replaces this with a direct logical connector, simplifying the phrasing by making the relationship between reflection and exchange more explicit and less qualified.

The French phrase 'de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide' (from there it returns to meet all that is solid) uses a somewhat literary and less direct expression. The English 'and which is intercepted by every Body that is solid' simplifies this by using the more common and active verb 'intercepted,' making the action clearer and more direct.

The French 'tissus' (fabrics, weaves) is a rich, metaphorical term evoking an intricate structure. The English 'Mixture' is a more common and general term, simplifying the original's figurative language and reducing its stylistic complexity.

The French 'Aussi' (also/therefore) is a concise transition. The English 'For this end' makes the sun's purpose more explicit. Additionally, 'animer tout par sa chaleur' (to animate/enliven everything with its heat) is expanded to 'for the livening and enlightning all things round him,' simplifying by explicitly detailing the sun's functions rather than relying on the broader implication of 'animer'.

The French 'On est bien embarrassé à le dire' (One is very much at a loss/embarrassed to say it) conveys a personal sense of difficulty with a slightly informal tone. The English 'is all the difficulty' simplifies this into a more abstract, impersonal, and formal statement, reducing the original's expressive nuance.

The French 'on s'en desabusa' (one was disabused of it) is a concise, idiomatic reflexive expression. The English 'the Error of this Opinion was found out' simplifies this by using a more analytical and periphrastic passive construction, making the meaning more explicit and easier to understand for a reader unfamiliar with the French idiom.

The original French uses a single, long sentence with a complex structure of subordinate clauses ('Comme...', 'que...', 'qu'enfin...') leading to the main verb 'on jugea'. The English translation simplifies this complex sentence structure by breaking it into shorter, more independent clauses, thereby reducing syntactic complexity and making the sentence easier to parse.

The French 'pretendües Planetes' (alleged/supposed planets) carries a subtle authorial skepticism. The English 'new discover'd Planets' simplifies this by offering a more neutral description, thereby removing the nuanced authorial commentary and making the statement more straightforward.

The French phrase 'à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...' (as to who would have remained master of the spots to name them as he wished...) is an elaborate clause detailing the nature of the quarrel. The English translation 'to whom they shou'd belong' significantly simplifies this by reducing its length and complexity, using more general terms and omitting the specific details about the power over naming.

chunks.source_manual: <P062>Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes, & j'en estois fort contente. Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Sçavans se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres. Souffrez, répondis-je, <UP></UP> qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune. Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage. Il se trouva que ce n'estoient point des Planetes, mais des nuages, des fumées, des écumes, qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil. Elles sont tantost en grande quantité, tantost en petit nombre; tantost elles disparoissent toutes, quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires. Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup, il y en a d'autres, & mesme assez longs, où il n'en paroist aucune. Il semble que le Soleil soit une matiere liquide, quelques-uns disent de l'Or fondu, qui boüillonne incessamment <NCP></NCP>, & produit des impuretez, qui par la force de son mouvement sont rejettées sur sa surface. Elles s'y consument, & puis il s'en produit d'autres. Imaginez-vous quels Corps étrangers ce sont là. Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre aussi grand que la Terre. Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil. D'autres disent que le Soleil paroît avec des Lunettes tout plein de Montagnes qui vomissent des flâmes, & que c'est comme un million de Monts Etna mis ensemble, mais on dit aussi que ces Montagnes sont une pure vision, causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes. Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes mesme, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects. Enfin, quoy que ce puisse estre que le Soleil, il ne paroist nullement propre à estre habité. C'est pourtant dommage, l'habitation seroit belle. On seroit au centre de tout, on verroit toutes les Planetes tourner regulierement autour de soy, au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizareries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement. Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable? Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse estre extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne. Vous n'y songez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Qui seroit dans le Soleil, verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes. Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout? Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature.</P062>
chunks.target_manual: <P047>I am not pleas'd with that at all, said the Marquiese: You told me the other Night, that the Philosophers and learned Men had given Names of Philosophers, Astronomers and Mathematicians to the several Countries of the Moon, and I was very well satisfy'd, and think it but just, that since the Kings and Princes possess the Earth, that they ought to suffer Philosophers and Astronomers to rule in the Moon and the Stars, without incroaching upon 'em. What, said I, Madam, Will not you allow Kings and Princes some Corner of the Moon, or some Star, to take their part in time of need? As to the Spots in the Sun, they can be of no manner of use to 'em; for it has been found, they are not Planets, but Clouds of Smoak and Vapours, and, as it were, a Scum arising from the Surface of the Sun; for sometimes they appear in great Quantities, sometimes in less, and at other times they dis-appear; sometimes they join in one, and other times they are dispers'd and dissipated; so that it shou'd seem, the Sun is a liquid Substance; some say, 'tis of melted Gold, <UP>which boils incessantly, and produces those Impurities</UP>; and by the force of its Motion, throws upon the Surface its Scum and Dross; and as those consume, new ones are produc'd. Pray, Madam, fansie to your self what strange Bodies these Spots of the Sun must be; there are some of 'em full as big as the Globe of the Earth; judge then what a great quantity there must be of this melted Gold, and of the Extent of this vast Ocean of Light and Fire, which we call the Sun. They say, the Sun appears, through Telescopes, to be full of great Mountains which vomit Flames, and that it is, as it were, a Million of Mount Aetna's, join'd together; but at the same time they acknowledge that these Mountains may be altogether visionary, and that they are nothing else but the Effects of the Glasses of the Telescopes. To whom shall we trust then, when these very Glasses, to which we owe so many new Discoveries, deceive us? In fine, Let the Sun be what it will, it does not at all seem proper to be inhabited; and yet 'tis pity, for the Situation wou'd be extreamly fine; its Inhabitants wou'd be plac'd in the Centre of the Universe, and wou'd see all the other Planets turn regularly round 'em, whereas we observe infinite Irregularities in their Course; and 'tis only because we are not in a proper Situation to consider 'em, as not being in the Centre of their Motion. Is it not hard, that there is but one place in the Universe, where the Study of the Stars wou'd be easie, and that that place alone shou'd be uninhabitable? You do not think, whilst you speak, said the Marquiese, were any living Creature in the Sun, he wou'd see neither Planets, nor fixed Stars; nor, indeed, any thing; the brightness of the Sun wou'd render all things else invisible; and if there were Inhabitants in the Sun, they wou'd be apt to believe themselves the only People in Nature.</P047>

explanations: The French "engager aux Princes" (to pledge/mortgage to the Princes) uses a specific financial term. The English translation simplifies this to the vaguer, more common phrase "to take their part." Additionally, "quelque partie de la Lune" (some part of the Moon) is rendered as "some Corner of the Moon," which is more colloquial and less formal, simplifying the vocabulary.

The French "qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil" (which rise on/from the Sun) is concise. The English translation "arising from the Surface of the Sun" adds the word "Surface," making the description more explicit. This explicitation simplifies the imaginative effort required from the reader by providing a clearer image.

The French "toutes" (all), indicating that sometimes all the spots disappear, is omitted in the English translation "and at other times they dis-appear". This omission simplifies the text by removing a specific detail about the totality of the disappearance, thereby reducing textual density.

The French phrase "elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble" (several of them gather together/put themselves together) describes a process of multiple spots coalescing. The English translation "they join in one" is a more concise and less descriptive phrase, focusing on the result rather than the process, thereby simplifying the original imagery and phrasing.

The French sentence includes the descriptive clause "quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires" (sometimes they are lighter, sometimes darker/more black). This final element is entirely omitted from the English translation of the sentence, which ends with "dispers'd and dissipated;". This omission simplifies the text by reducing its length and descriptive density.

The French phrase "& puis il s'en produit d'autres" (and then others are produced from it/of them) includes the temporal connective "puis" (then) and uses a reflexive/pronominal construction "s'en produit". The English "new ones are produc'd" omits "then" and simplifies the structure to a more direct passive voice with the common term "new ones," making the expression more straightforward.

The French "quels Corps étrangers ce sont là" (what foreign/strange Bodies these are there) is concise. The English translation "what strange Bodies these Spots of the Sun must be" explicitly adds "these Spots of the Sun," clarifying the referent of "Corps étrangers." This explicitation simplifies the reader's task by removing the need to infer the subject from the context.

The French "Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre..." (There is such a one of them which is perhaps...) uses a nuanced and somewhat indefinite construction. The English "there are some of 'em..." is a more direct and common phrasing, simplifying the slightly hypothetical or illustrative tone of the original French.

The French phrase "quoy que ce puisse estre que le Soleil" (whatever the Sun may be) is a somewhat formal and complex subjunctive construction. The English translation "Let the Sun be what it will" uses a common, more direct idiomatic expression, simplifying the syntactic structure.

The French "l'habitation" in "l'habitation seroit belle" refers to the dwelling, the act of inhabiting, or the state of being inhabited. The English translation uses "the Situation" ("for the Situation wou'd be extreamly fine;"), which is a more general and common term in this context, referring broadly to the location or circumstances. This choice simplifies the vocabulary slightly by opting for a broader term.

The French "On seroit au centre de tout" (One would be at the center of everything) uses the impersonal pronoun "On" and the general term "tout" (everything). The English translation "its Inhabitants wou'd be plac'd in the Centre of the Universe" makes this more concrete and specific by naming "Inhabitants" and specifying "Universe." This explicitation simplifies comprehension by providing a clearer, less abstract image.

The French "pour en bien juger" (to judge them well) implies a more definitive act of assessment. The English translation "to consider 'em" uses the more general and common verb "consider," which means to observe or think about, rather than to pass a specific judgment. This choice simplifies the vocabulary by opting for a less specific and less formal term.

The French "pitoyable" in "Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable?" means pitiful or lamentable, conveying a strong sense of regret or misfortune. The English translation "Is it not hard," uses "hard" (in the sense of harsh or unfortunate), which is a more common and less emotionally intense word, simplifying the vocabulary by reducing the affective strength of the original term.

The French original "puisse estre extremément facile" (could be extremely easy) includes the intensifier "extremément" (extremely). The English translation "wou'd be easie" omits this intensifier, simplifying the description by reducing its intensity and textual density.

The French "Qui seroit dans le Soleil" (Whoever/Anyone might be in the Sun) uses the general and impersonal pronoun "Qui." The English translation "were any living Creature in the Sun" replaces this with the more concrete and descriptive phrase "any living Creature." This specification makes the hypothetical scenario easier for the reader to visualize, thus simplifying by making the subject more explicit and relatable.

The French "Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout?" is a concise rhetorical question meaning "Does the Sun not blot out everything?". The English translation replaces this with a more explicit declarative statement: "the brightness of the Sun wou'd render all things else invisible;". This transformation simplifies the text by spelling out the underlying assertion of the question, making the point more direct and less reliant on the reader's grasp of the rhetoric.

The French sentence "Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature" uses an emphatic cleft sentence structure ("Ce seroient...qui..."). The English translation "and if there were Inhabitants in the Sun, they wou'd be apt to believe themselves the only People in Nature" simplifies this to a more straightforward conditional sentence. Additionally, the French "seroient bien fondez à se croire" (would be well-founded/justified in believing) is rendered as "wou'd be apt to believe," using "apt," a simpler and more common term than the concept of being "well-founded" or "justified."

chunks.source_manual: <P063>J'avoüe que je m'estois trompé, répondis-je, je ne songeois qu'à la situation où est le Soleil,& non à l'effet de sa lumiere; mais vous qui me redressez si à propos, vous voulez bien que je vous dise que vous vous estes trompée aussi; les Habitans du Soleil ne le verroient seulement pas. Ou ils ne pourroient soûtenir la force de sa lumiere, ou ils ne la pourroient recevoir, faute d'en estre à quelque distance, & tout bien considéré, le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles; encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour estre habité; mais voulez-vous que nous poursuivions nostre Voyage des Mondes? Nous sommes arrivéz au centre qui est toûjours le lieu le plus bas dans tout ce qui est rond, il faudroit presentement retourner sur nos pas, & remonter. Nous retrouverons Mercure, Venus, la Terre, la Lune, toutes Planetes que nous avons visitées. Ensuite c'est Mars qui se presente. Mars n'a rien de curieux que je sçache, ses jours ne sont pas d'une heure entiere plus longs que les nostres; ses années valent deux de nos années. Il est plus petit que la Terre, il voit le Soleil un peu moins grand & moins vif que nous ne le voyons; enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arreste. Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter avec ses quatre Lunes ou <RW>Satellites</RW>! Ce sont quatre petites Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, comme nostre Lune tourne autour de nous. Mais, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, pourquoy y a-t-il des Planetes qui tournent autour d'autres Planetes qui ne valent pas mieux qu'elles? Serieusement il me paroîtroit plus regulier & plus uniforme que toutes les Planetes, grandes & petites, n'eussent que le mesme mouvement autour du Soleil!</P063> <P064>Ah! Madame, répliquay-je! Si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les <RW><NCP>Tourbillons</NCP></RW> de Descartes, ces Tourbillons dont le nom est si terrible, & l'idée si agreable, vous ne parleriez pas comme vous faites. La teste me dust-elle tourner, dit-elle en riant, il est beau de sçavoir ce que c'est que les Tourbillons. Achevez de me rendre folle, je ne me ménage plus, je ne connois plus de retenuë sur la Philosophie; laissons parler le monde, & donnons-nous aux Tourbillons. Je ne vous connoissois pas de pareils emportemens, répris-je; c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet. Ce qu'on appelle un Tourbillon, c'est un amas de matiere dont les parties sont détachées les unes des autres, & se meuvent toutes en un mesme sens; permis à elles d'avoir pendant ce temps-là quelques petites mouvemens particuliers, pourveu qu'elles suivent toûjours le mouvement general. Ainsi un Tourbillon de vent <UP></UP>, c'est une infinité de petites parties d'air, qui tournent en rond toutes ensemble, & enveloppent ce qu'elles rencontrent. Vous sçavez que les Planetes sont portées dans la matiere celeste, qui est d'une subtilité, & d'une agitation prodigieuse. Tout ce grand amas de matiere celeste, qui est depuis le Soleil <UP></UP>jusqu'aux Etoiles fixes, tourne en rond, & emportant avec soy les Planetes <UP></UP>, les fait tourner toutes en un mesme sens autour du Soleil, qui occupe le centre; mais en des temps plus ou moins longs, selon qu'elles en sont plus ou moins éloignées. Il n'y a pas jusqu'au Soleil qui ne tourne; mais il ne tourne que sur luy-mesme, parce qu'il est justement au milieu de toute cette <IIM>matiere celeste</IIM>; & vous remarquerez en passant, que quand la Terre seroit dans la place où il est, elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle-mesme.</P064> <P065>Voila quel est le grand Tourbillon dont le Soleil est comme le Maistre; mais en mesme temps les Planetes se composent de petits Tourbillons particuliers à l'imitation de celuy du Soleil. Chacune d'elles en tournant autour du Soleil, ne laisse pas de tourner autour d'elle-mesme, & fait tourner aussi autour d'elle en mesme sens une certaine quantité de cette matiere celeste, qui est toûjours preste à suivre tous les mouvemens qu'on luy veut donner, s'ils ne la détournent pas de son mouvement general. c'est-là le Tourbillon particulier de la Planete & elle le pousse aussi loin que la force de son mouvement se peut étendre. S'il faut qu'il tombe dans ce petit Tourbillon quelque Planete moindre que celle qui y domine, la voilà emportée par la grande, & forcée indispensablement à tourner autour d'elle, & le tout ensemble, la grande Planete, la petite, & le Tourbillon qui les renferme, n'en tourne pas moins autour du Soleil. C'est ainsi qu'au commencement du Monde nous nous fismes suivre par la Lune, parce qu'elle se trouva dans l'étenduë de nostre Tourbillon, & tout à fait à nostre bienséance. Jupiter dont je commençois à vous parler, fut plus heureux ou plus puissant que nous. Il y avoit dans son voisinage quatre petites Planetes, ils se les assujettit toutes quatre, & <UP></UP> nous qui sommes une Planete principale, croyez-vous que nous l'eussions esté, si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy? Il est quatre-vingt-dix fois plus gros que nous, il nous auroit engloutis sans peine dans son Tourbillon, & nous ne serions qu'une Lune de sa dépendance, au lieu que nous en avons une qui est dans la nostre, tant il est vray que le seul hazard de la situation décide souvent de toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir.</P065> <P066>Et qui nous assure, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que nous demeurerons toûjours où nous sommes? Je commence à craindre que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher d'une Planete aussi entreprenante que Jupiter, ou qu'il <IIM>ne vienne</IIM> vers nous pour nous absorber; car il me paroist que dans ce grand mouvement, où vous dites qu'est la matiere Celeste, elle devroit agiter les Planetes irregulierement, tantost les approcher, tantost les éloigner les unes des autres. <UP>Nous pourrions aussi-tost y gagner qu'y perdre, répondis-je</UP>, peut-estre irions-nous soumettre à nostre domination Mercure & Venus, qui sont de petites Planetes, & qui ne nous pourroient résister. Mais nous n'avons rien à esperer ny à craindre; les Planetes se tiennent où elles sont, & les nouvelles conquestes leur sont défenduës, comme elles l'étoient autrefois aux Rois de la Chine. Vous sçavez bien que quand on met de l'huile avec de l'eau, l'huile surnage. Qu'on mette sur ces deux liqueurs un Corps extremement leger <UP></UP>, l'huile le soûtiendra, & il n'ira pas jusqu'à l'eau. Qu'on y mette un autre Corps plus pesant, & qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur, il passera au travers de l'huile, qui sera trop foible pour l'arrester, & tombera jusqu'à ce qu'il rencontre l'eau, qui aura la force de le soûtenir. Ainsi dans cette liqueur composée de deux liqueurs qui ne se mêlent point, deux Corps inégalement pesants se mettent naturellement à deux places differentes, & jamais l'un ne montera, ny l'autre ne descendra. Qu'on mette encore d'autres liqueurs qui se tiennent separées, & qu'on y plonge d'autres corps, il arrivera la mesme chose. Representez-vous que la Matiere Celeste qui remplit ce grand Tourbillon, à differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres, & dont les pesanteurs sont differentes, comme celles de l'huile & de l'eau, & des autres liqueurs. Les Planetes ont aussi differentes pesanteurs; chacune d'elles par consequent s'arreste dans la couche qui a précisément la force necessaire pour la soûtenir, & qui luy fait équilibre, & vous voyez bien qu'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais.</P066>
chunks.target_manual: <P048>I confess, said I, I am mistaken, I consider'd only the Situation of the Sun, without the Effects of its Light. But, pray, Madam, allow me to tell you, that you who have corrected me so justly, may also be mistaken your self: The Inhabitants of the Sun wou'd not so much as see it self; for they wou'd be incapable to support the dazling of his Light, or unable to receive it, by being too near; and all things well consider'd, the Sun wou'd be a Country of blind Men only. So that, once for all, I conclude, the Sun cannot be inhabited; and if you please, Madam, we will continue our Journey to the other Worlds: We are now come to the Centre, which is the lowest Point in all Circular Figures; and therefore must return back again, and go upwards. In the Way, we shall find Mercury, Venus, the Earth, and the Moon; all which Planets we have visited.</P048> <P049>The next that presents it self to our Observation is Mars, who contains nothing rare or curious that I know of: His Days are not a full Hour longer than ours, but his Years are double the length of ours. Mars is less than the Earth, and his Inhabitants see the Sun neither so big, nor so bright as we do. In short, Mars is not worthy the pains of a longer Discourse; but 'tis very curious to observe Iupiter, and his four Moons, or <RW>Guards</RW>: they are four little Planets, which turn round Iupiter, as our Moon turns round us. But, says the Marquiese, interrupting me, why are there some Planets attending upon others, who, it may be, are no better than themselves? In my Opinion, it wou'd be more regular and uniform if all the Planets, great and small, had but one Motion round the Sun. Ah, Madam! said I; if you understood the Tourbillions, or Whistlings of Monsieur Des Cartes, whose Name is so terrible, and Idea's so agreeable, you wou'd not talk at that rate. Let my Brains turn round, said she, laughing, if they will; I long to know what these Tourbillions are; make haste therefore to satisfie me, I'll manage my self no longer, but henceforth abandon all my Thoughts to Philosophy, without Reserve, let the World talk what they please; but let me understand these Whirling's. I did not think you capable of such Transports, said I, Madam; and I am sorry they have not a fitter Object: But to satisfie you, a Tourbillion is a heap of Matter, whose parts are disjoin'd one from another, yet moving round all one way; each little part being allow'd a particular Motion of its own, provided always they do not obstruct the general Circular Motion. As for Example; A Tourbillion of Air, <UP>call'd a Whirl-wind, or a Hurricain</UP>, is an infinite quantity of little Particles of Air, turning all round together, carrying along every thing they meet with in their way: You know that the Planets are carry'd round in the Celestial Matter, which is incredibly subtile and swift; all that <UP>vast Ocean,</UP> and Mass of Celestial Substance, which is between the Sun, <UP>and the Sphere</UP> of the fixed Stars, turns round, and carries with it the Planets one way, <UP>from East to West,</UP> round the Sun, which is plac'd in the Centre; but in shorter or longer time, as they are distant or nearer the Centre, all things turn round, even the Sun it self; but he turns round upon his own Axis: And you are to observe thus; if the Earth were in the middle of the Celestial Matter, as the Sun is, she wou'd also turn round upon her own Axis, like that: This is that great Tourbillion, of which the Sun is, as it were, Governor; but at the same time, all the Planets have little Whirlings peculiar to themselves, in imitation of that great one, the Sun; notwithstanding, they are all carry'd round the Sun, yet every one of them turns round upon his own Axis, and sweeps along with him a share of the Celestial Substance, which yields easily to any Impulse of Motion it receives, provided that does not obstruct its general Motion round the Sun; and this is call'd the particular Whirling, or Tourbillion of a Planet, which extends as far as <UP>the Sphere of its Activity</UP> can reach; and if it falls so out, that any lesser Planet than that which governs the Tourbillion comes in its way, 'tis carry'd with it, and indispensably forc'd round it; but yet that does not hinder both the greater Planet, and the lesser, with their Whirlings, to turn round with the great Tourbillion of the Sun. 'Twas thus that, after the Creation of the Universe, the Earth carry'd the Moon round it self, because the Moon fell within the Extent or Sphere of Activity, and forc'd its Obedience. Iupiter, of whom I have said somewhat already, was happier or stronger than we; there fell four little Planets in his Neighbourhood, and he subdu'd 'em all four: Our Earth, which is now a chief Planet, had it fallen within the Tourbillion of Iupiter, you may easily believe he wou'd have forc'd us to have turn'd round him also, Iupiter being ninety times bigger than our Earth; and then we had been nothing but a Moon depending upon Iupiter, whereas now the Earth has a Moon of her own turning round her: So true it is, that Chance of Situation has decided our Fortune. Pray, what Assurance have we, said the Marquiese, that our Earth shall always remain in the same Situation? I am afraid we may make a Trip one Day or other, towards some Planet as dangerous as Iupiter, who may sweep us round with it self; or that some other stronger Planet may approach nearer to us; for I fansie, that the violent Motions of the heavenly Matter you speak of, may agitate and shake the Planets so irregularly, that it might sometimes bring 'em nearer together, and at other times remove 'em farther from one another. We might gain rather than lose by that Bargain, said I; for it may be, our Earth wou'd be carry'd near Venus and Mercury, which are little Planets, and cou'd not resist ours: But we have nothing either to hope or fear from such an Accident; the Planets must remain where they are, new Conquests are forbid them, as they were heretofore to the Kings of China. You know very well, when one mixes Oil and Water together <UP>in a Vessel</UP>, the Oil will swim above; and if you throw any very light thing into the Vessel, the Oil will support it, and it will not penetrate into the Water: Throw in any other thing, somewhat heavier, of a proportionable weight to penetrate the Oil, which is too weak to stop it; 'twill fall upon the Water, and swim, the Water being sufficiently strong to bear it up. So that this Vessel, full of two Liquors, which does not mingle together two Bodies of an unequal weight, rests naturally in two different Positions, the one above the other; so as the lightest can never descend, the heaviest can never ascend. If you add other Liquors that will not mingle together, and throw as many Bodies into 'em of proportionable weight, 'twill still be the same thing. Imagine to your self, that the Celestial Substance which fills the vast Tourbillion, or Whirling of the Sun, is compos'd of different Coats, wrapp'd within one another, <UP>like an Onion</UP>; these Coats are of different weights and force, as Oil and Water, and other Liquors. The Planets also are of different weights; and by consequence, every one of the Planets must stop upon that Coat proportionable to its weight, and which has necessary strength for supporting it, and keeping it in an equal Balance; and you will perceive it is not possible in Nature they can remove from thence.</P049>
