explanations: The French "encore un coup" (once again/another time) is expanded to "once for all, I conclude." The addition of "I conclude" simplifies the rhetorical transition by explicitly framing the statement as a final deduction, making it easier for the reader to follow the argument's progression.

The French exclamatory phrase "Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter..." (But the pretty thing that Jupiter...) is simplified to the more declarative and less effusive "'tis very curious to observe Iupiter...". Additionally, "Satellites" is supplemented by "Guards," a more common and evocative term for the period, simplifying the newer scientific term for better readability.

The French phrase "Serieusement il me paroîtroit plus regulier & plus uniforme que..." (Seriously it would appear to me more regular and more uniform that...) is simplified to the more common English idiom "In my Opinion, it wou'd be more regular and uniform if...". This change uses a more conventional and direct expression, simplifying the formality.

The French phrase "vous ne parleriez pas comme vous faites" (you would not speak as you do) is simplified to the more colloquial English idiom "you wou'd not talk at that rate." This reduces the formality of the original phrasing.

The somewhat detached French "il est beau de sçavoir" (it is fine/good to know) is simplified to the more direct and urgent "I long to know." "Achevez de me rendre folle" (Finish making me mad) is simplified and rephrased to the goal-oriented "make haste therefore to satisfie me." The metaphorical "donnons-nous aux Tourbillons" (let's give ourselves to the Vortices) is simplified to the concrete desire for comprehension: "let me understand these Whirling's."

The French "c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet" (it's a pity that they *only* have the Vortices as an object) is simplified to "I am sorry they have not a fitter Object." The English version changes the nuance, implying the current object is unfit rather than lamenting its exclusivity, thus simplifying the specific complaint.

The translator simplifies by adding "call'd a Whirl-wind, or a Hurricain" as an explanation for "Tourbillon de vent," using more common English terms. Also, "enveloppent ce qu'elles rencontrent" (envelop what they encounter) is rendered as the more dynamic and easily visualized "carrying along every thing they meet with in their way."

The French phrase "d'une agitation prodigieuse" (of a prodigious agitation) is simplified to "swift." This substitution uses a more common adjective and focuses on a single, easily understood aspect (speed) of the complex idea of "prodigious agitation."

The complex French negative litotes "elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle-mesme" (it still could not do less than to turn on itself) is simplified to the more direct affirmative statement "she wou'd also turn round upon her own Axis." The concluding "like that" further simplifies what might have been a more elaborate comparative clause.

The French verb phrase "se composent de" (compose for themselves / are made of / form) is simplified to "have." This uses a more common and direct verb, simplifying the vocabulary used to describe the planets' characteristics.

The French construction "le tout ensemble... n'en tourne pas moins autour du Soleil" (the whole together... turns no less around the Sun) is simplified by restructuring it as "but yet that does not hinder both... to turn round...". The English phrase "does not hinder" explicitly states the lack of obstruction, making the meaning more direct than the French double negative implication.

The reflexive causative French "nous nous fismes suivre par la Lune" (we made ourselves be followed by the Moon) is simplified to the direct active voice: "the Earth carry'd the Moon round it self." Further, the polite and somewhat vague French "tout à fait à nostre bienséance" (entirely to our convenience/propriety) is simplified to the stronger and more direct "and forc'd its Obedience," clarifying the power dynamic.

The French hypothetical question "croyez-vous que nous l'eussions esté, si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy?" (do you believe that we would have been [one of his satellites], if we had found ourselves near him?) is simplified by making the implied scenario explicit: "had it fallen within the Tourbillion of Iupiter, you may easily believe he wou'd have forc'd us to have turn'd round him also." This reduces the reader's inferential burden.

The vivid French phrase "il nous auroit engloutis sans peine dans son Tourbillon" (he would have swallowed us without difficulty in his Vortex) is omitted, reducing textual density and a strong image. Furthermore, "tant il est vray que le seul hazard de la situation décide souvent de toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir" (so true it is that the mere chance of situation often decides all the fortune one is to have) is simplified to "So true it is, that Chance of Situation has decided our Fortune," by omitting "souvent" (often) and condensing "toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir."

The French dramatic expression "que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher" (that we might not do the folly of approaching) is simplified to the more colloquial and less intense phrase "we may make a Trip one Day or other, towards." This change lessens the gravity of the concern expressed.

The active and assertive French "peut-estre irions-nous soumettre à nostre domination Mercure & Venus" (perhaps we would go to submit Mercury & Venus to our domination) is simplified to the more passive construction "for it may be, our Earth wou'd be carry'd near Venus and Mercury." This removes Earth's agency and the explicit idea of conquest, simplifying the description to one of proximity.

The French term "un Corps extremement leger" (an extremely light body) is simplified by using the more general and common English word "thing" ("any very light thing"), reducing the formality and potential scientific specificity of "Corps."

The French general pronouns in "jamais l'un ne montera, ny l'autre ne descendra" (never will one rise, nor the other descend) are simplified by making the referents explicit: "so as the lightest can never descend, the heaviest can never ascend." This clarification makes the sentence easier to understand by directly naming the subjects based on their previously described properties.

The impersonal French constructions "Qu'on mette encore d'autres liqueurs" (Let one put again other liquors) and "qu'on y plonge d'autres corps" (that one plunges other bodies into them) are simplified to the more direct conditional phrasing "If you add other Liquors" and "throw as many Bodies into 'em." The English also adds "of proportionable weight," making an implied condition explicit, simplifying the reader's task of inferring this detail.

The translator simplifies the abstract description "couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres" (layers that envelop one another) by adding the concrete simile "like an Onion." This provides a familiar visual analogy, making the concept of layered celestial matter more accessible and easier to imagine.

The French "la couche qui a précisément la force necessaire pour la soûtenir, & qui luy fait équilibre" (the layer that has precisely the necessary force to support it, and which makes equilibrium with it) is simplified by adding the clarifying phrase "proportionable to its weight" in the English translation: "that Coat proportionable to its weight." This explicitly states the reason for the planet's position, which is only implied in the French, thus simplifying the inference required by the reader.

chunks.source_manual: <P067>Je conçois, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs. Plust à Dieu qu'il y eust quelque chose de pareil qui les reglast parmi nous, & qui fixast les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables. Me voila fort en repos du costé de Jupiter. Je suis bien-aise qu'il nous laisse dans nostre petit Tourbillon <SC>avec nostre Lune unique</SC>. Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément, & je ne luy envie point les quatre qu'il a.</P067>
chunks.target_manual: <P050>I understand very well, said the Marquiese, how these different Weights are regulated, according to their several degrees: Wou'd to God, there were some such Order amongst us Mortals, to confine every Man to the Station that is fit for him. I am now no longer in fear of Iupiter; I am satisfy'd that he will leave us at ease in our own little Whirling, or Tourbillion <SC>;</SC> I am easily pleas'd, and do not envy Iupiter his four Moons.</P050>

explanations: The original French 'que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs' (that these weights regulate the ranks/orders very well) uses the somewhat abstract term 'les rangs.' The translation changes the structure to 'how...' and replaces 'les rangs' with the more explicit and descriptive phrase 'according to their several degrees.' This clarifies the mechanism of regulation and makes the concept less dense and more accessible, which is a form of simplification.

The French presents a wish for 'quelque chose de pareil' (something similar) followed by two defining subjunctive clauses ('qui les reglast...' and 'qui fixast...'). The translation simplifies this complex structure by introducing a more concrete noun 'some such Order' and then uses a single infinitive phrase ('to confine...') to express the desired function. Additionally, the phrase 'naturellement convenables' (naturally suitable) is simplified to the more common and direct 'fit.' This reduces sentence complexity and uses more direct vocabulary.

The French 'Me voila fort en repos du costé de Jupiter' (literally, 'Here I am, very at ease/restful concerning Jupiter') is a slightly more formal and somewhat periphrastic expression. The English 'I am now no longer in fear of Iupiter;' simplifies this to a more direct statement using common vocabulary and a more standard emotional expression, making it less idiomatic to French and more straightforward.

The French 'Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément' (literally, 'I am of a mood/inclination to limit myself easily' or 'I am inclined to be easily content') is a periphrastic construction. The English translation 'I am easily pleas'd,' simplifies this into a much more direct, concise, and common idiomatic expression, reducing the structural complexity and lexical density.

chunks.source_manual: <P068>Vous auriez tort de les luy envier, repris-je, il n'en a point plus qu'il ne luy en faut. Dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil, les Lunes ne reçoivent & ne luy renvoyent, qu'une lumiere assez faible. Il est vray que comme il tourne sur luy-mesme en dix heures, & que ses nuits, qui par consequent <IIM>n'en durent que cinq</IIM>, sont fort courtes, quatre Lunes ne paroîtroient pas si necessaires, mais il y a autre chose à considerer. Icy sous les Pôles, on a six mois de jour, & six mois de nuit. C'est que les Pôles sont les deux extremitez de la Terre les plus éloignées des lieux où le Soleil donne à plomb, & sur lesquels il paroit faire sa course. La Lune ne tient, ou paroist tenir la même route à peu prés que le Soleil, & si les Habitans des Pôles voyent le Soleil pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un an, & pendant toute l'autre moitié ne le voyent point, ils voyent aussi la Lune pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un mois, c'est à dire, pendant quinze jours, & ils ne la voyent point pendant toute l'autre moitié. <IIM>Les années de Jupiter</IIM> en valent douze des nostre, & il doit y avoir dans cette Planete deux extremitez opposées, où l'on ait des jours & des nuits de six ans entiers. <IIM>Des nuits</IIM> de six ans sont bien longues, aussi est ce principalement pour elles que je crois que les quatre Lunes sont faites. Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée, fait son cercle autour de luy en dix-sept jours, la seconde en sept, la troisiéme en trois jours & demy, la quatrième en quarante-deux heures. Leurs courses estant coupées justement par la moitié pour ces malheureux <UP></UP> Pays qui ont six ans de nuit, il ne se peut passer vingt & une heures, qu'on ne voye paroistre au moins la derniere Lune. C'est quelque consolation pendant des tenebres d'une durée si ennuyeuse; mais quelque lieu que l'on habite dans Jupiter, ces quatre Lunes vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles <UP></UP> du monde. Tantost elles se lèvent toutes quatre ensemble, & puis se separent selon l'inégalité de leur cours; tantost elles sont toutes à leur Midy rangées l'une au dessus de l'autre, tantost <RW>on les</RW> voit toutes quatre sur l'Horizon à des distances égales; tantost quand deux se levent, deux autres se couchent; sur tout j'aimerois à voir ce jeu perpetuel d'Eclipses qu'elles font, car il ne se passe point de jour qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil, & asseurément les Eclipses s'estant renduës si familieres en ce Monde-là, elles y sont un sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celuy-ci.</P068> <P069><SC>Gens de nostre Lune</SC>, me fait douter que Jupiter en ait beaucoup sur le Habitans de siennes, & je croy qu'un des avantages ausquels ils puissent le plus raisonnablemént pretendre, c'est de leur faire peur. <UP>Par exemple, dans celle qui est la plus proche de luy, ils le voyent trois cents soixante fois plus gros que nostre Lune ne nous paroist, car il la surpasse autant en grosseur. Il est, je croy, beaucoup plus proche d'eux, qu'elle n'est de nous, sa grosseur en augmente encore. Ils fent comme des Colonies de Jupiter; qu'elles eussent receu de luy, s'il estoit possible, leurs Loix & leurs Coûtumes; que par consequent elles luy redissent quelque sorte d'hommage, & ne regardassent la grande Planete qu'avec respect. Ne faudroit-il point aussi, luy dis-je, que les quatre Lunes envoyassent de temps en temps des Députez dans Jupiter, pour luy prester ferment de fidelité? Pour moy, je vous avoüe que le peu de superiorité que nous avons sur les Gens.</UP></P069>
chunks.target_manual: <P051>You wou'd be to blame if you shou'd, said I; for he has no more than what is necessary for him; considering the great distance he is from the Sun, his Moons receive and reflect but a very faint Light. 'Tis true, that Iupiter turns upon his own Axis in the space of ten Hours, his Nights are but four Hours long; and being so short, one wou'd think he had no great need of four Moons: But you must consider, in our Earth, <RW>under the North and South Poles</RW>, there are six Months of Day, and six Months of Night; because the two Poles being the two Points of the Earth, remotest from those Countries and Places, upon which the Sun darts his beams directly, and over which, to our Apprehensions, he seems to perform his Course: The Moon holds, or appears to us to hold the same Road with the Sun: So that if the Inhabitants <UP>near the South and North Poles</UP> see the Sun during one half of his yearly Course, and then lose his Light during the other half, it must follow, that they see the Moon during one half of her monthly <RW>Revolution</RW>, and lose her during the other half; that is, for the space of fifteen Days. One of Iupiter's Years is twelve of ours, and there must be two opposite Poles in that Planet where there are Days and Nights of six Years long apiece. A Night of six Years long is very long, and I believe these four Moons were chiefly created for that reason: The highest of the four, as to Iupiter, performs its Course round him in seventeen Days, the second in seven Days, the third in three Days and an half, and the fourth in forty two Hours. These Revolutions being thus divided by equal halves in these unhappy <IIM>Climates </IIM>, where there are six Years of continued Night, one and twenty Hours cannot pass without their seeing appear, at least, the last of the four Moons; which is a very great satisfaction, during so long and irksome a Darkness: But upon whatever place of Iupiter you shou'd inhabit, these four Moons wou'd represent to your view one of the most agreeable Sights in Nature: Sometimes they rise all four together, then they separate according to the inequality of their Motions; sometimes they see 'em over their Heads, directly above one another; at other times they see 'em appear above their Horzion, at equal distances; at another time, two of the four are rising, when the other two are setting; but above all, I shou'd be pleas'd to see their constant Eclipsing one another, or the Sun; for there passes no Day, without one of the two; and since Eclipses are so familiar to that World, they must certainly be a Divertissement to them, whereas they fight the Inhabitants of our Earth.</P051>

explanations: The explicit logical connector 'par consequent' (consequently) is omitted. This simplifies the sentence structure by making the causal link implicit rather than overtly stated, thus reducing syntactic load and improving flow.

The formal, somewhat passive phrasing 'ne paroîtroient pas si necessaires' (would not seem so necessary) is replaced by the more colloquial and active construction 'one wou'd think he had no great need,' simplifying the register and sentence structure for easier comprehension.

The impersonal French construction 'il y a autre chose à considerer' (there is something else to consider) is simplified to a direct, active address 'you must consider,'. This change reduces formal distance and simplifies the sentence by making it more conversational and direct, enhancing readability.

The concise 'Icy' (Here) is expanded to 'in our Earth,' and 'les Pôles' (the Poles) is specified as 'the North and South Poles.' This explicitation simplifies by pre-empting potential reader ambiguity and providing immediate context, aiding readability for a general audience.

The qualifying phrase 'à peu prés' (approximately/nearly) is omitted from the translation. This simplification removes a nuance of scientific precision, making the statement more absolute and arguably easier to process for a lay reader by reducing detail.

The more general and slightly more formal term 'extremitez' (extremities) is replaced by 'Poles,' which in this astronomical context is a more common and specific term for a general reader, thereby simplifying the vocabulary.

The French emphatic sentence structure 'aussi est ce principalement pour elles que...' (also it is principally for them that...) is rephrased into a more standard and direct English declarative sentence 'and I believe... for that reason,' simplifying the syntax and improving directness.

The impersonal French 'l'on habite' (one inhabits) is translated using direct address 'you shou'd inhabit.' This simplifies the formality of the original, making the text more engaging and direct for the reader, consistent with the work's popularizing aim.

The astronomical reference 'à leur Midy' (at their Meridian/Noon) is replaced with the simpler, more visual description 'over their Heads.' This simplifies the concept for a non-scientific audience by using more common and easily pictured language. The grammatical subject also changes from the moons ('elles sont') to the observers ('they see 'em'), making the description more experiential and less abstract.

The detailed clause specifying the nature of the eclipses ('qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil' - that they do not eclipse each other, or that they do not eclipse the Sun) is significantly condensed to the vague phrase 'without one of the two.' This is a simplification by reduction of textual density and length, omitting specific information for brevity.

chunks.source_manual: <P070>Et vous ne manquerez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, à faire habiter ces quatre Lunes, quoy que ce ne foient que de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre pendant ces nuits? N'en doutez nullement, répondis-je. Ces Planetes n'en sont pas moins dignes d'estre habitées pour avoir le malheur d'estre asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.</P070> <P071>Je voudrais donc, reprit-elle, que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter <UP></UP>, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete suspédüe sur leurs testes à une distance assez petite. En verité, si les Gaulois craignaient anciennement que le Ciel ne tombast sur eux, les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter <UP></UP>. C'est peut-estre là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont, dit- elle, au lieu de celle des Eclipses, dont vous m'avez asseuré qu'ils sont exempts, & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise? Il le faut de necessité absolüe, répondis-je. L'Inventeur du troisième Systême dont je vous parlois l'autre jour, le celebre Ticho-Brahé <UP></UP>, un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais, n'avoit garde de craindre les Eclipses, comme le Vulgaire les craint, il passoit sa vie avec elles. Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis, la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit estoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin, Ticho-Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit estre malheureuse, & retournoit promptement se renfermer chez luy, sans oser commencer la moindre chose.</P071>
chunks.target_manual: <P052>And you will not fail, I hope, says the Marquiese, to bestow Inhabitants upon these four Moons, though they be little, inferior Planets, and only made to enlighten the Inhabitants of a greater, during their long Nights. You need not doubt of it, said I, Madam; these four Planets are no less deserving of Inhabitants, because they are so unhappy as to be subject to, and turn round a more important Planet. I wou'd, says the Marquiese, have the Inhabitants of these four Moons to be Colonies of Iupiter, and receive their Laws and Manners from thence, and pay Homage and Respect to Iupiter, and not to look upon that great Planet, but with Veneration. And wou'd you not also, said I, have these four Moons to send Ambassadors, from time to time, to the Inhabitants of Iupiter, and swear Fealty to him? For my part, we having no Authority over the Inhabitants of our Moon, makes me think that Iupiter has no more over the Inhabitants of his four; and I believe, one of the Advantages he has most reason to brag of, is, that he frightens 'em. For Example; The Inhabitants of that Moon next to Iupiter, see him three hundred and sixty times bigger than our one Moon appeareth to us: And as I believe that little Moon to be much nearer to Iupiter than Ours is; so his greatness must be by that considerably augmented; and they must constantly see that monstrous Planet hanging over their Heads, at a very small distance. And if it be true, that the Gauls of old, apprehended the falling of the Heavens: The Inhabitants of that Moon have more Reason to fear the falling of Iupiter. It may be, said she, they have that fright, instead of that of the Eclipses, which you told me, they are free from; and which must be supply'd by some other piece of Folly. It must be so infallibly, said I, Madam, for the great inventer of the third System, of which I spoke to you the other Day, the Ticho-Brahe one of the greatest Astronomers that ever liv'd, was far from fearing Eclipses as the Vulgar do; but instead of that, he fear'd, if the first he met (as he went out of his House <UP>in the Morning)</UP> were old, or if a Hare happen'd to cross his way, he instantly return'd home, shut himself up, and did believe that day to be unlucky; nor wou'd he dare to attempt <IIM>Business of the smallest Consequence </IIM>.</P052>

The French phrase 'C'est peut-estre là aussi,' which includes the adverb 'aussi' (also/indeed) adding a slight complexity or emphasis, is simplified to the more direct and common English phrase 'It may be.'
The verb 'assuré' (assured), which can imply a greater degree of formality or certainty, is replaced by the more common and simpler verb 'told'.

The emphatic French phrase 'de necessité absolüe' (of absolute necessity) is condensed into the single adverb 'infallibly'. The core structure 'Il le faut' (It is necessary) is rendered as the common English idiom 'It must be so', simplifying the original's somewhat formal and emphatic construction.

The final clause of the French sentence, 'il passoit sa vie avec elles' (he spent his life with them [eclipses]), which adds descriptive detail about Tycho's familiarity with eclipses, is omitted in the translation. This omission reduces the length and density of the overall translated sentence.

The original French uses a direct rhetorical question ('Mais croiriez-vous bien...') to engage the listener. The translation replaces this with a more straightforward declarative transitional phrase ('but instead of that, he fear'd,'), simplifying the sentence structure by removing the interrogative form and reducing its rhetorical complexity.

The French 'la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit estoit une Vieille' (the first person he met was an Old Woman) specifies the person as 'an Old Woman'. The English translation 'the first he met ... were old' generalizes this to an 'old' person, removing the specific gender and the concrete noun 'Vieille', which can carry stronger folkloric connotations. This generalization simplifies by reducing specificity and potentially softening cultural nuance.

chunks.source_manual: <P072>Il ne seroit pas juste, <IIM>reprit-elle</IIM>, aprés que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la crainte des Eclipses, que les Habitans de cette <UP></UP> Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune <UP></UP>, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques momens. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.</P072> <P073>De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vist la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoyent jamais veüe. D'abord le <NCE>Journal des Sçavans</NCE> de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres-raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'asseure bien que ce n'est point une vision, on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce <RW>mouvement</RW> est d'une année; & enfin, grace à toutes les peines que se donnent les Sçavans, <NCP></NCP> on sçait dans Jupiter que nostre Terre est un Monde. Les Curieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.</P073>
chunks.target_manual: <P053>It is not just, said the Marquiese, that since that great Man was not free from the Fear of Eclipses for nothing, that the Inhabitants of that little Moon, shou'd come off at an easier rate: Let us give 'em no Quarter, but force 'em to submit to the common Law <UP>of Nature</UP>, and oblige 'em to yield to some other Folly. But since I will not trouble my self to guess at this time, what that may be, pray solve me one difficulty, which my Fancy has just now suggested; if the Earth be so little, in respect of Iupiter; does <UP>the Inhabitants of</UP> Iupiter see our Earth? I am afraid we are altogether unknown to 'em. Really, I believe it to be so, said I, for the Inhabitants of Iupiter must see the Earth ninety times less than Iupiter appears to us; which is too small to be perceiv'd by them; and all we can imagine for our advantage, is, to suppose that there are Astronomers in Iupiter, who after having taken a great deal of Pains, and fitting excellent Telescopes; and having chosen a very clear Night for making the Observation, they at last discover in the Heavens a little Planet, they had never seen before; and streight they set it down in the <NCE>Philosophical Transactions </NCE> of that Country. The rest of the Inhabitants of Iupiter, either never hear of it, or laugh at it if they do; the Philosophers themselves whose Opinion that discovery destroys, resolve not to believe it; and there are but some very rational People, that will trouble themselves with the thoughts of it. These Astronomers make new Observations; they again look upon this little Planet, and they begin to be assur'd that it is no Fancy but a real thing; then they begin to conclude, this little Planet has a Motion round the Sun; and after a thousand Observations, they at last find out that this Motion <RW>or Revolution</RW>, is performed in a Years time. So that, thanks to these learned Men, the Inhabitants of Iupiter know our Earth is a Planet and a World: The Curious are earnest to look on it through a Telescope; tho 'tis so little, 'tis hardly discoverable.</P053>

explanations: The French idiomatic expression "je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner" (I don't pride myself on being able to guess it/I don't claim to be able to guess it) is simplified to the more straightforward "I will not trouble my self to guess". Additionally, the verb "éclaircissez-moy" (clarify for me/enlighten me) is simplified to the more common "solve me" in the context of a "difficulty".

The French impersonal construction "Il faudroit qu'il vist..." (It would be necessary that he saw... / He would have to see...) which uses a subjunctive, is simplified to the more direct modal verb construction "must see". The implicit object of comparison "le" (it, referring to Jupiter) is also made explicit as "Iupiter appears to us", aiding comprehension.

The French text uses future tense ("Il y aura" - there will be) and future perfect tense ("auront enfin découvert" - will have finally discovered) to describe the hypothetical scenario. The English translation shifts to the present tense ("there are", "they at last discover"), simplifying the temporal complexity of the original and making the narrative more immediate for the reader.

The French phrase "forment le dessein de n'en rien croire" (literally, "form the plan/design to believe nothing of it") uses a slightly more elaborate and formal phrasing. The English translation "resolve not to believe it" simplifies this by using the more common and concise verb "resolve" and by streamlining the negative construction "n'en rien croire" to "not to believe it."

The French text repeatedly uses the impersonal pronoun "On" (one/they), creating a general narrative voice. The English translation consistently replaces "On" with the specific subject "These Astronomers" or "they." This explicitation of the agent simplifies the sentence structure for the reader by making it more direct and less ambiguous, though it alters the original's narrative style.

The French phrase "la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper" (literally, "sight can barely still catch it") employs a mildly personified and somewhat literary construction with "la veüe" (sight) as the active subject. The English translation simplifies this into a more direct, less figurative, and objective statement: "tho 'tis so little, 'tis hardly discoverable," focusing on the object's property rather than the act of perception.

chunks.source_manual: <P074>Si ce n'estoit, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de sçavoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me representerois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nostres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considerent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce-là? Quelles Gens l'habitent?</P074>
chunks.target_manual: <P054>If it were not, said the Marquiese, very disagreeable for me to believe, that our Earth is not to be perceiv'd by the Inhabitants of Iupiter, but by the help of a Telescope, I shou'd find an Infinite Pleasure in imagining, I shou'd see those Telescopes <SC></SC> pointing towards us; and ours from a mutual Curiosity are levell'd at them, whil'st those two Planets gravely considering one another, the Inhabitants of both ask at one and the same time, What World is that? What People are those?</P054>

explanations: The French uses litotes ('point trop agreable,' meaning 'not too pleasant,' an understatement) and 'sçavoir' (to know). The translation simplifies this by using the direct 'very disagreeable' and the more common/less epistemically strong 'to believe,' making the expression more straightforward and less rhetorically nuanced.

The French uses the impersonal pronoun 'on' (one/people) and the general 'nous' (us) with the concise 'de dedans Jupiter' (from within Jupiter). The translation simplifies this by specifying 'our Earth' and 'the Inhabitants of Iupiter,' making agents and objects explicit and the source of perception more concrete, which enhances readability.

The French term 'Lunettes d'approche' (literally 'glasses of approach,' referring to early telescopes or spyglasses) is simplified to the more common and standard English term 'Telescope,' making the vocabulary more accessible.

The French 'dressées vers nous' (literally 'set up/aimed towards us') uses a more formal verb construction. The English 'pointing towards us' employs a simpler, more common verb ('to point') and a more direct phrasal structure, simplifying the language.

The French 'demandent l'une de l'autre' (ask one another) has 'les Planetes' (the Planets) as its implied subject from the preceding clause 'les Planetes s'entre-considerent'. The translation simplifies this by changing the agent of asking from the metaphorical 'Planets' to the literal 'Inhabitants of both,' making the concept less figurative and more direct.

chunks.source_manual: <P075><IIM>Cela ne va pas si viste que vous pensez</IIM>, repliquay-je. Quand on verroit nostre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoistroit, nostre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse estre habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sçait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-estre mesme sommes-nous cause qu'on y <UP>a fait le procés</UP> à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous estions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, asseurément <UP>leurs Cristophles Colombs ne sçauroient manquer d'employ</UP>. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, <NCP>qui est fort petit</NCP>, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne <RW>avec les siennes</RW>. Voila assez de Planetes pour embarasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.</P075>
chunks.target_manual: <P055>Don't go so fast, Madam, said I; suppose, the Inhabitants of Iupiter, cou'd see our Earth; yet, they cou'd never see us, or so much as suspect our Earth to be inhabited; or if any Body were Fool enough to imagine it, God knows, how he wou'd be laugh'd at and ridicul'd by the rest of the Inhabitants. And it may be, we are the Cause, that some Philosophers in that World have been <UP>sued and persecuted</UP> for this Opinion: However, I believe, that the Inhabitants of Iupiter are employed enough in the discovery of their own Planet, without troubling themselves with the thoughts of us. And had Christopher Columbus been of that Country, and understanding Navigation so well, he cou'd not have wanted employment. And the People of that World know not the hundredth part of its own Inhabitants; whereas, in Mercury <NCP>(which is a very little Planet)</NCP> they are all Neighbours one to another, and converse familiarly together; and they esteem it, as but a Walk to go round their little World; and if the Inhabitants of Iupiter do not see us, you may easily judge, they can far less perceive Venus and Mercury, both which are more diminutive Worlds, and further distant from it than we: But in lieu of this, they see Mars, and there are four Moons, and Saturn <RW>with the five that belong to him</RW>. There are Planets enough, to perplex all the Astronomers there: And Nature has had the goodness to hide from 'em what remains of the Universe.</P055>

explanations: The French "Cela ne va pas si viste que vous pensez" (That doesn't go as fast as you think) is simplified to the more direct and idiomatic "Don't go so fast." The explicit comparison "que vous pensez" (as you think) is omitted, streamlining the expression and reducing its length.

The French presents two sequential hypothetical conditions: "Quand on verroit nostre Terre de dedans Jupiter" (If one were to see our Earth from Jupiter) and the subsequent "quand on l'y connoistroit" (when one knew/recognized it there). The translation simplifies this structure by omitting the explicit second condition of 'knowing/recognizing' ("quand on l'y connoistroit"), reducing the layered hypothetical to a single act of seeing and thus simplifying the sentence structure.

The detailed relative clause "qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous estions" (who wanted to maintain that we existed/Earth was inhabited), which specifies the reason for the philosophers' prosecution, is simplified and condensed into the short prepositional phrase "for this Opinion." This significantly reduces syntactic complexity and textual length, relying on context for the specific meaning.

The French "je croirois plus volontiers que" (I would more willingly believe that) is simplified to "I believe, that." The nuance of "plus volontiers" (more willingly/rather), which indicates a specific preference or readiness in the speaker's belief, is omitted, making the statement more direct and reducing its lexical density.

The translation simplifies the original French in two significant ways: first, it omits the explicit causal premise "Elle est si grande, que..." (It [Jupiter] is so large, that...), which sets up the subsequent analogy, reducing textual density. Second, it replaces the abstract, plural "leurs Cristophles Colombs" (their Christopher Columbuses, implying generic Jovian explorers) with the singular, historically specific "Christopher Columbus," thereby simplifying the conceptualization by using a more concrete and directly relatable figure.

The translation simplifies the French sentence by: 1) Omitting the modal expression "Il faut que..." (It must be that...), which conveys deduction or necessity, thus changing the statement into a more direct assertion and simplifying the sentence structure. 2) Reducing the nuanced phrase "ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation" (do not know even by reputation) to the more general "know not," thereby omitting a qualifying detail and reducing lexical density.

The French phrase "ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes" (those among them who are Astronomers), an elaborate relative clause construction, is simplified to the more concise adjectival phrase "all the Astronomers there." This streamlines the syntax, reduces length, and makes the reference more direct.

chunks.source_manual: <P076>Quoy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous comptez cela pour une grace? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand <RW>Tourbillon</RW> seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres, qui avoient esté cachees; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.</P076>
chunks.target_manual: <P056>What, said the Lady Marquiese, do you look upon that as a Favour? Without doubt, said I, Madam, there is in this great Tourbillion <RW>or whirling of the Sun</RW>, Sixteen Planets. And Nature, who is willing to save us the labour of studying all their Motions, has discover'd to us only seven of them; and is not that a great Favour. But we who are not sensible of this Grace, have so ordered the matter that by our Endeavours we have found out the other nine, which Nature had conceal'd from us, and we are sufficiently punish'd for it, by the great Pains and Labour, which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy.</P056>

explanations: The French "Tourbillon," a specific term from Cartesian physics referring to a vortex of matter around a celestial body, is made more accessible by the addition of the explanatory phrase "or whirling of the Sun." This simplifies the text for readers unfamiliar with the technical term by providing a more common and descriptive equivalent, enhancing readability.

The translator simplifies the French "une assez grande faveur" (a rather great favor / a great enough favor) to "a great Favour." By omitting the nuance conveyed by "assez" (enough, rather, quite), the phrase becomes more direct and reduces stylistic density, simplifying the original expression.

Within this clause, the idiomatic and concise French phrase "nous faisons si bien que" (we do/manage so well that) is translated into the more analytical and explicit "have so ordered the matter that by our Endeavours". This unpacks the French idiom, making the process ("by our Endeavours") and the deliberate action ("ordered the matter") clearer, thereby simplifying the understanding of an idiomatic construction for the reader.

Within this sentence, the implication of the French phrase "que l'Astronomie demande" (that Astronomy demands/requires) is made more explicit in the English translation "which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy." This addition clarifies that the "Pains and Labour" are specifically required *for the study of* astronomy, whereas the French implies this more abstractly. This explication simplifies the text by reducing the inferential load on the reader.

chunks.source_manual: <P077>Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, repliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraischement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nostres, & que par consequent il a <IIM>des Pays</IIM>, où une seule nuit dure des quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui estant assez élevé pour estre hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil <RW>dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point</RW>.</P077>
chunks.target_manual: <P057>I see, answer'd she, by the number of sixteen Planets, that Saturn must have five Moons. He has so, said I, Madam, and two of the five are discover'd very lately, but there is yet something more remarkable in that Planet; for his Year is as long as thirty of ours; and consequently there are <IIM>Climates in that World [translates "des Pays",</IIM> where one Night lasts for fifteen Years together. Can you guess what Nature has intended for the enlightning of Nights so long and dreadful? She was not satisfied to bestow on Saturn five Moons; but has also given him a great Circle or Ring, which environs him entirely, and which is elevated sufficiently high enough to be out of the shadow of this Planet. It reflects the Light of the Sun perpetually upon the <RW>Inhabitants of Saturn, who have the Misfortune to live in that Climate</RW>, that is, so long a time depriv'd of the influence of his Beams.</P057>
source_segments: Comme son année est de trente des nostres, & que par consequent il a des Pays, où une seule nuit dure des quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses.
dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point.

explanations: The original French sentence is a single, multi-clause construction that links a premise ('Comme son année...'), a consequence ('& que par consequent il a des Pays...'), and an imperative command ('devinez...'). The English translation simplifies this complex sentence structure by dividing it into two shorter sentences. The first sentence presents the premise and consequence, while the second poses the question as a separate interrogative sentence. This structural simplification enhances readability by breaking down the dense information into more manageable units.

The French phrase 'dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point' (literally, 'in the places that do not see it [the Sun]') is a concise and somewhat abstract description of the areas receiving reflected light. The English translation replaces this with a significantly more elaborate and explicit passage. While this increases the length of the specific phrase, it simplifies the text for the reader by directly explaining the human impact and significance of these areas (i.e., the plight of Saturn's inhabitants in prolonged darkness and how the ring alleviates this). This reduces the inferential load on the reader and makes the scientific point more accessible, thus enhancing readability at the cost of the original's stylistic subtlety and conciseness.

chunks.source_manual: <P078>En verité, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <IIM>de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-mesme avec étonnement</IIM>, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroist bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Estres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas esté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'estoit pas la peine d'en donner à Venus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mesmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a <IIM>point de Lune</IIM>. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas. Vous avez veu des <SC>Phosphores</SC>, de ces matieres liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. <SC>Peut-estre Mars a-t-il</SC> de grands Rochers fort élevéz, qui sont des <SC>Phosphores</SC> naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumiere qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sçauriez nier que ce ne fust un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'alumer de toutes parts dés que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous sçavez encore qu'il y a en Amerique des Oyseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que sçavons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oyseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous costéz, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?</P078>
chunks.target_manual: <P058>Well, said the Marquiese, <NCP>(with the Air of a Person return'd to herself from some great astonishment)</NCP> all that you say is contriv'd with wonderful Order, and sure Nature has seen and provided for the necessity of some animate Beings; and that the distribution of these Moons, was not a work of Chance, since they are bestowed only upon these Planets, that are at a great distance from the Sun, the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn; for Venus and Mercury have no need on 'em; they enjoy but too much Light already; and their Nights are very short; and it may be the Inhabitants of this Planet esteem Night a greater benefit of Nature, than the Day it self. But hold, said Madam the Marquiese, it seems to me, that Mars, who is farther distant from the Sun than the Earth, <IIM>ought to have a Moon too </IIM>. I must confess, said I, Madam, he has none; but certainly, the Inhabitants of that Planet enjoy some other advantage, which supplies that defect. You have seen several bodies <SC></SC>, both liquid and dry, which draw in the Light of the Sun; and afterwards shine and cast a light in the dark. It may be, that there are <SC></SC> great Rocks very high; which are naturally of such a kind of Substance, as to receive great Provision of Light in the Day time from the Sun, which they restore in the Night; and if it be so, you cannot deny, but it must be a very pleasant Scene or Representation, to see all those Rocks from all Quarters begin to shine, as soon as the Sun is down, and make Magnificent Illuminations without Art or Expence. You know also that in America, there are certain Birds, which shine so in the dark; that one may read by their Light, as well as by that of a Candle; and who knows, but there are many of these Birds in the Planet Mars, which fly about and enlighten that World as soon as the Sun is set?</P058>

explanations: The French interjection "En verité" (In truth/Indeed) is simplified to the more common and conversational English interjection "Well," making the tone less formal.

The French phrase "il paroist bien que" (it appears well that / it is quite apparent that) is simplified to the more direct and common English assertion "sure," reducing formality and enhancing readability.

The English "are bestowed only upon" simplifies the French idiomatic and somewhat complex passive construction "Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux" (lit. "There has fallen of them in share only to"), using more straightforward vocabulary and sentence structure.

The translation "have no need on 'em" is a simpler and more direct expression compared to the French periphrastic construction "ce n'estoit pas la peine d'en donner à" (it was not worth the trouble/pains to give some to), reducing structural complexity.

The translation makes the agent ("the Inhabitants of this Planet") explicit, whereas the French "qui les comptent" (who count them) is more implicit. This explicitation simplifies comprehension by removing a layer of inference for the reader. The phrasing "it may be ... esteem" also simplifies the structure for expressing "comptent apparemment" (apparently count/consider).

The translation "some other advantage, which supplies that defect" is more explicit about the function of the unknown resources than the French "des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas" (resources that we do not know). By specifying that these advantages "supply that defect" (i.e., the lack of a moon), the translator simplifies the reader's task of inferring this connection.

This descriptive sentence is simplified by: replacing the specific term "Phosphores" with the more general "several bodies"; condensing the two French verbs describing light absorption ("s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent" - soak it up, and are penetrated by it) into the single, simpler English phrasal verb "draw in"; and rendering "jettent un assez grand éclat" (cast a rather great radiance) with the more common vocabulary "shine and cast a light." This reduces lexical specificity and descriptive density.

The core simplification within this sentence is the replacement of the specific phrase "qui sont des Phosphores naturels" (which are natural phosphors) with the more general and descriptive "which are naturally of such a kind of Substance." This avoids a potentially unfamiliar term, simplifying the vocabulary for a broader audience.

The French phrase "que ce ne fust" employs a subjunctive mood (imperfect subjunctive of être), which can be complex for readers. The English translation "but it must be" simplifies this by using a more direct indicative mood with a modal verb ("must be"), making the grammatical structure more accessible.
The English phrase "in the dark" is more common and simpler everyday vocabulary than the French "dans les tenebres" (in the darkness/gloom), which can have a more literary or formal connotation.

This interrogative clause is simplified in several ways: the temporal clause "dés que la nuit est venuë" (as soon as night has come) is rendered as the more concrete "as soon as the Sun is set"; the descriptive action "se dispersent de tous costéz" (disperse themselves in all directions) is reduced to the simpler and more common verb "fly about"; and the poetic, metaphorical phrase "& vont répandre un nouveau jour?" (and go to spread a new day?) is translated into the more direct and less figurative "and enlighten that World?" These changes simplify phrasing, vocabulary, and imagery.

chunks.source_manual: <P079>Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oyseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse esté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fust point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vrayment, repliquay-je, si <LS><IIM>vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites</IIM></LS>, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de mesme pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous estions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos testes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroist une habitation trop irreguliere. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'estoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échapées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez miserables. Il leur donne de la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.</P079> <P080>Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, au lieu que tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, repliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extremitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.</P080> <P081>Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde estoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne sçavent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique <IIM>trop badin & trop folâtre</IIM>. <NCE></NCE>.</P081>
chunks.target_manual: <P059>Your Rocks, and your flying Birds, said the Marquiese, do not at all satisfie me. I confess such objects wou'd be very pretty; but since Nature has given so many Moons to Saturn and Iupiter; 'tis a sign, that they are absolutely necessary as well to Mars. I shou'd have been glad that all the Worlds distant from the Sun, cou'd have had their Moons; and that Mars might not have been so disagreeably excepted. Oh! Madam, said I, <IIM>if you think it worth your pains to make any further Progress in Philosophy, you must accustom your self to such Exceptions</IIM>; in the best Systems, there are always some things that agree exactly; but there are other things, that one must adjust as well as one can, or leave them as they are, if there be no hopes to overcome the difficulty: Let us do so if you please with Mars; and since he is not favourable to us, say no more of him. And tell me if it wou'd not be strangely surprizing, if we were in the World of Saturn, to see above our Heads in the Night that great Ring in the form of a Semi-Circle, going from opposite Points of the Horizon; and which reflecting the Light of the Sun upon us, wou'd have the effect of a continu'd Moon. And shall we place no Inhabitants upon that great Ring, said the Marquiese, laughing? I answer'd her, that (tho in the Humour I was in, I was enclin'd to put Inhabitants every where) I confess, I dare not set any upon so irregular a Habitation; but for the five little Moons, there is no dispensing with them, for they must have Inhabitants. But some do imagine, that this Ring or great Circle is compos'd of Moons join'd very near together, having all an equal Motion, and turning one way, and that the five little Moons I spoke of, had only escaped out of this great Ring; what an Infinity of Worlds are there then in the Tourbillion or whirlings of Saturn? and yet whatever is the Cause, the Inhabitants of Saturn are miserable enough, notwithstanding the Assistance of this great Ring. 'Tis true, it gives them Light, but what kind of Light? Sure a very feeble one at that great distance from the Sun, where she her self appears to 'em, but as a little pale Star, a very faint heat and Light, so that if you wou'd carry some of the Inhabitants of Saturn to our coldest Countries, as Green-Land, or Lap-Land, you wou'd see 'em all of a sweat, and melt away with heat. You give me an Idea of Saturn, said the Marquiese; that makes me shiver with cold; whereas before you warm'd me as much with the descriptions you gave me of Mercury. There is a Necessity, said I, that the two Worlds that are at the extremity of this great Tourbillion, must be contrary one to another in every thing. At that rate, said she, the Inhabitants of Saturn must be very wise; for you told me the Inhabitants of Mercury were down-right mad. If the People of Saturn, said I, be not wise, they are at least in all Appearance so, and are very flegmatick, they know not what it is to laugh; and who take a whole days time at least, to answer the most trifling Question: They wou'd have look'd upon the grave Cato <IIM>the Censor</IIM>, as <IIM>too wild and youthful for their Conversation </IIM>.</P059>

explanations: The French "Cela ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly" (That wouldn't fail to be pretty/That would still be pretty) uses a nuanced negative litotes. The English "I confess such objects wou'd be very pretty" simplifies this by converting it to a more direct affirmative statement, making the original nuanced phrasing more straightforward. The addition of "I confess" also contributes to a more conversational and accessible tone.

The French active construction "ne nous fust point venu faire une exception" (had not come to make an exception for us/had not become an exception for us) is an idiomatic and somewhat complex phrasing. The English passive construction "might not have been so disagreeably excepted" simplifies this into a more direct and common passive voice, reducing the structural complexity.

The French "il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez" is a complex impersonal modal construction using the subjunctive. The English "you must accustom your self" simplifies this to a direct personal modal verb, significantly reducing structural complexity and making the obligation clearer.

The French idiomatic phrase "si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout" (if one despairs of being able to overcome it/succeed with it) is relatively complex. The English "if there be no hopes to overcome the difficulty" simplifies this by using more straightforward vocabulary and a less idiomatic construction, making the condition easier to understand.

The French "Quoy que je sois d'humeur... à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment" (Although I am of a mind/disposition... to send them everywhere quite boldly) uses a somewhat formal and idiomatic phrasing to express inclination. The English "(tho in the Humour I was in, I was enclin'd to put Inhabitants every where)" rephrases this using the more common verb "enclin'd" and a more straightforward structure, making the expression of inclination slightly more accessible.

The French "on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler" (one cannot avoid populating them) is a concise idiomatic phrase where the necessity of populating is implicit in "les peupler". The English translation "there is no dispensing with them, for they must have Inhabitants" simplifies this by first translating the idiom more directly and then explicitly stating the consequence ("for they must have Inhabitants"), which makes the meaning more readily understandable and less reliant on inferring from the idiom.

The French sentence uses a complex conditional structure with multiple subjunctive verbs ("n'estoit," "se suivissent," "eussent," "fussent") to present a hypothesis. The English translation simplifies this significantly by rephrasing the conditional as a declarative statement about what "some do imagine" and using indicative mood or past participle forms ("is compos'd," "join'd," "having," "had only escaped") instead of subjunctives. This makes the sentence grammatically less complex and more direct.

The French "mais quelle lumiere!" is an exclamatory phrase implying the poor quality of the light through rhetorical question. The English translation "but what kind of Light? Sure a very feeble one" simplifies by making this implication explicit. Adding "Sure a very feeble one" removes the need for the reader to infer the nature of the light, making the meaning more direct and accessible.

The French "suër à grosses gouttes" (to sweat in large drops/profusely) is a vivid descriptive phrase. The English "all of a sweat" is a more common, idiomatic, and slightly simpler expression. Furthermore, "expirer de chaud" (to expire from heat) uses the somewhat formal "expirer." The English "melt away with heat" uses a more vivid and common phrasal verb, simplifying the vocabulary for a popular audience.

The French adverb "tantost" (recently, a short while ago, just now) is simplified to the more common and general English adverb "before" (within the larger clause "whereas before you warm'd me"). This is a vocabulary simplification, replacing a slightly more archaic/specific term with a very common one.

The French "Il faut bien... que les deux Mondes... soient opposées" uses the subjunctive mood ("soient") within an impersonal modal construction. The English translation "There is a Necessity... that the two Worlds... must be contrary" simplifies this by using the indicative mood ("must be"), making the grammatical structure more straightforward for an English reader and avoiding the subjunctive.

The French "Ainsi" (Thus, So) is a general logical connector. The English "At that rate" is a more colloquial and vivid idiom that frames the Marquise's deduction in a more conversational and arguably simpler way than a more literal or formal connector. The shift from the general "on est" (one is/they are) to the more specific "the Inhabitants of Saturn must be" also makes the statement more explicit and less abstract.

The French "Ce sont Gens qui ne sçavent ce que c'est que de rire" (These are People who do not know what it is to laugh) uses a common French presentational structure ("Ce sont Gens qui..."). The English translation "they know not what it is to laugh;" simplifies this by starting directly with the pronoun "they", making the sentence structure more direct and less periphrastic.

The French adjectives "badin" (joking, playful, light-hearted) and "folâtre" (frolicsome, skittish) describe specific nuances of lightheartedness. The English translation simplifies these distinct terms to the more general and common adjectives "wild and youthful," which represent a reduction in semantic specificity for broader comprehensibility.

chunks.source_manual: <P082>Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lens. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nostre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extremitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractere fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différens. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'estre icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.</P082> <P083>Du moins, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nostre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grace à la Nature d'estre Homme, & non pas Beste, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moy je veux luy rendre grace d'estre sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grace d'estre jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & <UP></UP> belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vostre Tourbillon, ou de la temperature de vostre Pays.</P083> <P084>Mon Dieu! repliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a esté donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considerables, un goust qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, repliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles Fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez veu jusqu'icy.</P084>
chunks.target_manual: <P060>There is a thought come into my Head, said the Marquiese; all the Inhabitants of Mercury are very lively, and the Inhabitants of Saturn extremely dull: Now upon our Earth, we have a mixture of both, some are very airy, and some as insipid: Does not that proceed from our being situate in the middle, between these two Worlds, that we participate so of the Qualities of both these Extremes; and there is no fixt settled Character of Mankind; some resemble the Inhabitants of Mercury, others of Saturn; and we are a mixture of all the several kinds of People, that inhabit all the other Planets? I like that Idea well enough, said I, we are of such an extravagant Composition, that one wou'd really believe, that we were collected and drawn together from all the other Worlds. And at this rate, 'tis very convenient to live in ours, since here we see an abridgement of all that can be seen in the other Worlds. At least, said the Marquiese, Our World has one real advantage and conveniency, that it is neither so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Iupiter and Saturn: And we have the good luck over and above, to be born in a Climate of this Earth, that has neither excess of heat nor cold. And if a certain Philosopher thank'd Nature for being a Man and not a Beast, a Grecian, and not a Barbarian; for my Part, I thank her, that I inhabit the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and the most temperate Climate of that Planet. If you will trust me, said I, Madam, you ought to thank her for being young, and not old, young and handsome, and not young and ugly, young, handsome, and a French Woman, and not a young and handsome Italian. You have abundance of other Reasons of Gratitude, than those of the Situation of your Tourbillion, or the temperate Qualities of your Country. Good God, said she, suffer me to be grateful for every thing; even to the very Tourbillion where I was born: The measure of the Happiness bestow'd upon us, is too little to lose any part of it; and it is good to have such a Sense and Taste of the commonest and most considerable things, as to turn all to our Advantage and Profit. If we shou'd look after no other Pleasure or Satisfaction, than this World afforded, we shou'd enjoy but very few, expect 'em long, and pay dear for 'em. If Philosophy be the Pleasure, you propose, said I, Madam, I have the Boldness to wish, that when you remember the Tourbillions, you wou'd be pleas'd to think of me. Yes, answer'd she, provided you take care your Philosophy furnishes me always with new Pleasures. At least, for to Morrow, answer'd I, I hope you shall not want; for I have the fixed Stars prepared for you, which surpass all you have hitherto heard.</P060>

explanations: The French "cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que [participial clause for cause], [main clause stating effect]?" presents a somewhat elaborate hypothetical question structure. The English simplifies this into a more direct interrogative "Does not that proceed from [gerund phrase for cause], that [subordinate clause stating effect/explication]?". The French indirect phrasing "viendroit-il point de ce que" (would it not come from the fact that) is rendered as the more straightforward "Does not that proceed from," making the question's structure more linear and easier to parse.

The French "sont faits comme" (are made like/in the manner of) carries a slightly more concrete or constitutive implication. The translation to "resemble" simplifies this by using a more common and less nuanced verb, focusing on outward similarity rather than a deeper-seated makeup, thus simplifying vocabulary.

The French uses a presentational structure "une commodité... c'est que..." (an advantage... is that...). The English translation simplifies this sentence structure by adopting a more standard subject-verb-object form ("Our World has..."), which is more direct and conventional in English, potentially enhancing readability.

The French "moy je veux luy rendre grace" (for my part, I want to give her thanks) is simplified to the more direct "for my Part, I thank her." This removes the explicit expression of volition ("veux" - want) and presents the act of thanking as a direct statement, simplifying the verbal construction and reducing its length.

The French "que ceux que vous tirez de" (than those that you draw/derive from) uses the active verb "tirer" (to draw, derive). The English "than those of" simplifies this by omitting the explicit verb of derivation. This makes the phrase shorter and more direct, reducing its density and the slight metaphorical load of "tirer de".

The French "il n'en faut rien perdre" (one must not lose any of it) is an impersonal modal construction expressing an independent idea of obligation. The English translation simplifies the sentence structure by recasting this into an infinitive phrase "to lose any part of it," making it directly dependent on "is too little." This change creates a more concise and fluid sentence by simplifying the original clausal complexity.
